title: americas race debate not britains
story: Some people appear to be unhappy with the verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial. But perhaps there was never going to be a decision that pleased everyone. Had the jury found the Minnesotan police officer innocent of killing George Floyd last year, the Black Lives Matter mob would have resumed their riots – if they ever stopped. Upon finding Chauvin guilty, meanwhile, the jury was accused of appeasing the very same mob by those on the opposing side of the argument.I have no dog in this fight. It was an awful incident in a foreign land. The shocking killing of George Floyd will have sent shivers down the spine of anyone who saw the footage. The issue I have is with the drama being imported to this country. Violence by American police is an American issue that needs to be resolved by Americans. Protesting in the streets of London about something that happened thousands of miles away, chanting “end police brutality” and “ACAB”, makes little to no sense.It seems we must remind ourselves that America’s race debate is not the same as our race debate. Laws enforcing segregation and other forms of discrimination were still in place in America as late as the 1960s, when the UK was beginning to pass legislation on racial equality. “African Americans” developed their own culture, distinct from that of many people of black ethnicity in the UK. When Afro-Caribbean people from around the Commonwealth were invited to the mother country in the 1940s, 50s and 60s, they by and large integrated into British society and embraced British culture. There hasn’t been the same ide in the UK that we see in the States.Black Lives Matter is a global movement that grew out of the outrage following Floyd’s death. Yet its ideological arguments ignore any differences between nations.By contrast, Tony Sewell’s recent Commission on Race and Ethnic Disparities report took an evidence-based approach to examining inequalities in the UK, looking at the multiple causes of racial disparities rather than assuming racism. This upset many race-hustlers on the hard-Left of British politics who in their self-flagellation want to proclaim this to be an institutionally racist country. But when we move away from such isive rhetoric and look at the cold, hard facts, we see a nation that has thrived on building a multi-ethnic society with equal opportunities for all.This progress is threatened by importing US debates into the UK, thereby promoting an inaccurate and damaging narrative about race in our country. Divisions are stoked where they needn’t exist and where they often didn’t exist to begin with.Dawn Butler MP’s extraordinary comments in the House of Commons this week only further highlighted this point. In her response to a statement on the Sewell report, she used the term “racial gatekeepers” apparently in reference to the Commission and the equalities minister Kemi Badenoch, and accused them of “gaslightin’ (sic) on a national scale”. This is utterly disgraceful language for an MP to use in Parliament, and the Labour Party would do well to reprimand her for it, especially if they ever intend to reconnect with the common folks of this great nation.I can only speak for myself, but I would assume many ordinary people are fed up with this sort of toxic behaviour. When our politicians have lost all sense of nuance and responsibility, what hope is there for a sensible, reasoned debate?More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: italian skiver draws salary 15 years job never performed
story: In a crowded pantheon of bone-idle Italian public servants, he took the biscuit – not to mention the pay packet, the pension and all the perks.  Public health worker Salvatore Scumace allegedly managed to draw a salary and social security payments for 15 years without putting in a single day’s work, costing the Italian state no less than €538,000 (£464,410). He was supposed to be working as a fire safety officer in the Pugliese-Ciaccio Hospital in the town of Catanzaro, in the southern region of Calabria.Instead, the man hailed by one Italian newspaper on Wednesday as “the king of absenteeism”, skived off every day.He was spotted in the hospital just once – the day he went in to sign his work contract, back in 2005.Italy has for years had a chronic problem with “ghost” public officials who either never turn up for work or clock on and then promptly disappear for the day, sometimes holding down jobs in the private sector.Mr Scumace allegedly maintained the ruse by threatening the directors of the hospital, saying they and their relatives would be hurt if they revealed the fraud.He was only found out when Italian police found an anomaly when they compared a list of the hospital’s staff with the shifts that they worked.After an internal investigation, he was sacked last September from the job he had never performed.The 66-year-old has now been charged with aggravated extortion, fraud and abuse of office. Six of his bosses face charges of abuse of office for not having investigated the alleged fraud.Mr Scumace was not the only skiver on the hospital’s books. Another 57 employees of the hospital were recently denounced for absenteeism and are under investigation.On the days when they bunked off work, they were allegedly seen playing slot machines, drinking in bars or shopping at the supermarket.In 2015, a town on the Italian Riviera was swept up in a scandal over absenteeism after it emerged that council employees were clocking on for work and then heading to the beach, to the shops or even back to bed.A months-long covert investigation by police found that up to 75 per cent of council employees in San Remo, which is famed for its annual music festival and lies just across the border from Monaco and Nice, failed to show up for work.In one particularly brazen case, a security guard regularly turned up in his underpants, punched his time card and then promptly went back to bed.The guard lived on the premises of Palazzo Bellevue, the council’s main office, enabling him to clock in and then return to his flat.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: mi5 joins social media new era openness
story: Instead, Mr McCallum promised Britain’s domestic intelligence service would “become a more open and connected organisation”.The strategic decision to promote MI5 more widely includes the agency making its “slightly belated debut on social media” on Instagram, the social networking site used to share photographs and videos by its one billion users. Instagram is used by a much younger audience than Facebook, which owns it.Mr McCallum, who was appointed to the job last year at the age of 45, admitted the spy agency’s decision to launch its account on social media may be “routine” for most organisations but “more interesting when you’re in the business of keeping secrets”.It took the agency until 1993 to publicly acknowledge Dame Stella Rimington as its then chief and it remains the case that only the director-general is publicly avowed.In The , Mr McCallum said the agency needed to continue to attract a more erse workforce, calling time on any lingering association intelligence agencies might have with James Bond, the archetypal British spy, who is white, male and Oxbridge-educated.In a reference to his own upbringing, growing up in Glasgow and studying at the local university, Mr McCallum said MI5 would be “stronger” for recruiting people from “all kinds of places”, adding: “Including, crucially, people who have never thought of working somewhere like MI5.“I was once one of those myself growing up in Glasgow, it never crossed my mind that I’d end up working in national security, never mind in a senior role.”He said he wanted to ensure that people were not deterred from joining the agency just because of their “socio-economic background, ethnicity, sexuality, gender, disability, or which part of the country they happen to have been born in”.He did not identify James Bond by name but in reference to the fictional spy’s favourite cocktail, said: “We must get past whatever Martini-drinking stereotypes may be lingering by conveying a bit more of what today’s MI5 is actually like, so that people don’t rule themselves out based on perceived barriers.”Mr McCallum explained that MI5 need not see it as a contradiction in its requirement to be more open while running covert intelligence operations out of necessity.“But the other half of the dilemma is that MI5’s ability to keep the country safe and resilient also depends on our reaching out to others who can help us, and whom we in turn can help.”“We owe it to the public to be constantly striving to learn and improve and in our fast-moving world, with technology advancing at incredible speed, it would be dangerous vanity to imagine MI5 can build all the capabilities it needs inside its own bubble.”The choice of Instagram may raise eyebrows over its ownership by Facebook. As recently as this week, Facebook was condemned by Priti Patel, the Home Secretary with oversight of MI5, for new encryption measures which she said would make it harder for law enforcement agencies to catch paedophiles.MI5 has also frequently criticised social media and Mr McCallum recognised that.In his  article, he alluded to the need for tech companies to do more to “combat damaging State-backed disinformation, and to ensure that terrorists cannot use their platforms to plot or encourage terrorist acts”.But he also praised social media firms for their ability to keep people in touch, all the more crucial during the pandemic.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pass first time wait 8 months driving test ultimatum piling
story: Learner drivers have reported facing waits of eight months when booking tests and those who fail now face an average wait of 17 weeks to get a new slot.The backlog has prompted the DVSA to warn learners to only attempt their test when they are “completely ready to pass”.Learners are now complaining of feeling added pressure to pass, knowing failure could mean they must wait months to retake their test.Jade Bone, 24, is taking a test in Southampton on Thursday and is concerned at the consequences of not passing.“It’s going to be so long before I’m able to get another test if this one doesn’t go to plan,” she said. “That’s quite frustrating and a scary prospect, especially because it’s an expensive thing to do, having lessons.”Jack Hayes, 25, an AA Driving School pupil who is taking a test in Cardiff on Thursday, admitted he “really panicked” when it was announced that lessons would only resume last week.He said: “I booked (the test) back in October thinking there was plenty of time to learn before then.“I feel lucky to be one of the first people given the chance to take it, but I’ve had much less time to practise and prepare with my instructor.“There is also more pressure to actually pass than normal because the waiting list is so long before I can try to retake it, and more money would have to be spent on lessons to stay test-ready.”Only 46 per cent of tests in the year to March 2020 were passed, leading the DVSA to caution candidates that they should be “properly prepared”.The most common reasons for failing include not looking properly at a junction (22  per cent), not using mirrors correctly when changing lane or direction (17 per cent), and not moving off safely (8 per cent).Mark Winn, the DVSA chief driving examiner, said: “Learners should only take their driving test if they are completely ready to pass, and feel they’ve had sufficient practice driving on a variety of roads and in different conditions.“Thousands of people fail their test every year because of common errors which are potentially dangerous and avoidable.”Tests can be rescheduled free of charge if learners feel they need more time to prepare.Recent analysis found that the number of young people holding a driving licence numbers has fallen to the lowest level since current records began. Just 2.97 million people in Britain aged 16-25 hold a full licence, down from 3.32 million in March 2020.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: revealed britains greenest places quarter vegetarian 20 per
story: Britain's most eco-friendly places, where people are vegetarian and don't buy new clothes, have been revealed in a new study by the University of York.Scientists tracked the habits of 300,000 people over a year between February 2019 and October 2020 to work out their carbon footprint, asking them what they ate and bought, and how they travelled.The carbon footprint associated with the respondent’s lifestyle and consumption activities is calculated using an underlying model developed by the Stockholm Environment Institute at the University of York in partnership with the University of Leeds. They also used the World Wildlife Fund's carbon footprint calculator, making this the largest dataset of its type.The place where people had the most eco friendly lifestyles was Ceredigion in Wales, which scored 10.8 tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions. The average for a person using the calculator was 13.7 tonnes a year. More than 20 per cent of respondents spend nothing on clothing in a given month, and 10 per cent have solar panels. People who live there have a low carbon footprint across all areas of life, including travel and consumption, which could be linked to the rural lifestyle in the sparsely-populated area. It is full of wildlife, including seals and bottlenose dolphins.Dr Chris West at the Stockholm Environment Institute, University of York, said: The carbon calculator analysis showed people’s desire for a lower carbon future. Meeting our climate targets will require a combination of small and big changes, such as maintaining a reduction in international travel, which is needed to bring down personal footprints. “Changing consumer behaviours are a very important component of moving towards a low-carbon future, but these must also be complemented by a rapid transition towards renewable energy and a circular economy. The scientists also worked out the top five towns cities with a population of more than 250,000 which had the lowest carbon footprints.   Exeter, with 11.6 CO2e, was the best-scoring town or city, because more than 25 per cent of respondents sourced food locally, and 12 per cent had solar panels“Travel is another important area for carbon savings and as we come out of lockdown, making deliberate decisions to walk, cycle and safely use public transport are small choices that make a big difference. “In this critical year for environmental action, it’s vital that people also use their voices to ask businesses and governme nt to commit to the scale of transformation needed to tackle climate change and limit warming to 1.5°C.” More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sturgeons vaccine embarrassment highlights serious strategic
story: Not that it is likely to make much of a difference to the result of the Scottish Parliament elections next month, but Nicola Sturgeon finds herself in a bit of a quandary.An online hustings event organised by NUS Scotland became the talk of Twitter as videos of a very rattled first minister were gleefully shared. What brought her to the point where she seemed keen to deliver a Glasgow kiss to her Conservative opponent, Douglas Ross? The SNP have been put on the defensive for their insistence that an independent Scotland, as a fully-fledged member of the EU, would have chosen to abandon the European Medicines Agency and the EU approval and procurement process for the Covid vaccine, and would instead have joined the UK’s rather more successful efforts. This, of course, is untrue. We know this not just because not a single existing EU member exploited the rules to go it alone, and not just because Scotland, having just achieved EU membership, would be vanishingly unlikely to side with the rest of the UK it had just abandoned in favour of its newfound allies on the continent.No, we know the true SNP position because they told us so. In the wake of the government’s decision to forego the services of the European Medicines Agency and pursue its own approval system for the covid vaccine, the SNP health spokesperson in the Commons, Philippa Whitford, said: “The UK is losing the European Medicines Agency – one of the great advantages was working together to have a single licensing system that licensed new drugs right across Europe.”That seems a pretty straightforward and honest statement about the SNP’s approach to the EMA. But last night Sturgeon argued that, since it was at least legally possible for inidual EU members to have pursued their own path, nothing would have stopped Scotland doing the same. And she is right, of course. But that is hardly the point. The point is, would they have chosen to?Why is it that the first minister now refutes what her health spokesperson said? Was Whitford’s assertion that a single system to licence drugs across Europe was one of the EMA’s “great advantages” wrong? Was she reprimanded at the time for saying it? Did Sturgeon herself rush to the media to disown Whitford’s comments and to demand that she be removed from her front bench position?Of course, had Britain’s approach to securing the vaccine proved to be the disaster that the SNP – and every other opposition party – predicted, Sturgeon would not have been put on the defensive. She could have smugly (but with more sorrow than anger, obviously) regretted the vaccine nationalism of the UK government and offered future, closer co-operation with the EU as an incentive to vote SNP in May. That’s politics and few other party leaders would have resisted the temptation to take advantage of such calamitous consequences arising from an unforced error.Instead, with the UK’s (and therefore Scotland’s) vaccine rollout programme soaring ahead of the EU’s, the first minister doubled down and asked her audience to believe that she was always on TeamUK’s side anyway – what on earth would lead us to believe otherwise?The SNP are not the only party to regret their opposition to Britain’s withdrawal from the EMA. But for them it’s a more serious strategic issue than the one that confronts UK parties. Sturgeon has pinned her entire political career on attracting those who voted No in 2014 and Remain in 2016 to her cause. She is beloved in parts of the London-based media because she has given the impression that she is, at heart, a fully signed-up advocate of the European project. Unfortunately for her fanbase, this is far from the case. Her party spent more money and resources on a single parliamentary by-election in Shetland in 2019 than it did campaigning for a Remain vote in 2016. SNP campaigners for Remain were notable only by their absence, for they knew that a Leave vote across the whole UK would suit their short-term political purposes rather nicely, so long as a majority of Scots voted to remain. Just as Sturgeon only discovered her feminist credentials after she replaced Alex Salmond as first minister in 2014, so she has only found an enthusiasm for the EU since June 2016. Her party opposed Britain’s leaving the EMA because it fitted nicely into the “evil Tories abandoning nice, progressive Europe and taking Scotland with them” narrative. And when that narrative turned out to be wholly false, when it was proved that ministers’ decision to pursue an independent vaccine approval process was the right one, Sturgeon found herself either having to defend the indefensible (the position taken by Whitford in the Commons) or deny that such had ever been her party’s policy in the first place.Douglas Ross, the Scottish Conservative leader, is clearly getting under her skin with his constant attacks on her, while the new Scottish Labour leader, Anas Sarwar, seems to be having a good campaign by ostentatiously remaining above the fray and condescendingly criticising both Sturgeon and Ross for being a bad example to children – a comment that further irritated Sturgeon. It emerged today that the first minister, usually so assured in her media performances, has opted out of appearing in person on a BBC Question Time Holyrood election special, while every other party leader will be present. This campaign is proving much tougher for her than most expected, even though she remains virtually guaranteed to still be in her job come May 7.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: church england should stop unconditionally celebrating slave
story: It comes days after a Panorama investigation reported claims that UKME church staff subjected to racist abuse are forced to sign NDAs to buy their silence”.The report sets out almost 50 actions for the Church to implement. These include establishing new, salaried “racial justice officers'' in all 42 dioceses, and introducing a “racial justice Sunday'' once a year. It calls for at least one black and UKME candidate on every job shortlist and an aim of 15 per cent of General Synod, the Church’s legislative body, and all local church councils to have black and UKME representatives by 2030.On slavery, the taskforce drew a line on where the Church should stand regarding potentially offensive monuments and criticised it for taking “little action” so far. “The Church of England has taken little action in addressing the historic slave trade and its legacy since it made an apology at General Synod in 2006 for its involvement in the trade. “Regarding monuments and the built environment, deciding what to do with contested heritage is not easy. The taskforce called for a “healthy revision of memory and history in a way that will provide scope for education and formation”.“Decades of inaction carry consequences and this inaction must be owned by the whole Church,” it said.“A failure to act now will be seen as another indication, potentially a last straw for many, that the Church is not serious about racial sin.”The conclusions come on the same day that the Board of Deputies (BoD) published its own report on racial inclusivity in the Jewish community, which aimed to “to learn more about the experiences of Black Jews, Jews of Colour and Sephardi, Mizrahi and Yemenite Jews... and make recommendations for how our community can do better”. The BoD made similar recommendations to the Church, saying that organisations involved in rabbinic training should encourage under-represented ethnic groups to apply for communal roles, and that Jewish schools should ensure that their secular curriculum engages with black history, slavery and the legacy of colonialism.It also called for communal venues to conduct bag searches for all visitors so as not to stigmatise people who look different, without compromising on security. The Church of England’s report follows comments made by the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev Justin Welby, in February 2020 in which he said the Church remained ”deeply institutionally racist” in an address to General Synod.Just months later, following the murder of George Floyd, the Archbishop said that statues in Canterbury Cathedral are also going to be looked at very carefully to see if they should be there.He added that some will have to come down but that it is not his decision and that monuments would be put in context.The Cathedral later confirmed that all of its items are under review to ensure that any connected with slavery, colonialism or contentious figures from other historic periods are displayed with clear contextual information to avoid “any sense of aggrandisement”.The number of clergy who identify as part of a UK minority ethnic background has historically been low. In the Church of England, one in 25 serving clergy come from black, Asian and minority ethnic backgrounds.Of the 42 diocesan bishops across the country, the only one from a BAME background is Guli Francis-Dehqani, the Bishop of Chelmsford. Archbishop Welby, and the Archbishop of York, the Most Rev Stephen Cottrell, said they welcomed the report and would implement some of its recommendations immediately. This includes: working with General Synod to encourage it to co-opt 10 UKME candidates and inviting UKME clergy observers to attend House of Bishops as participant observers for three-year periods until there are six bishops from ethnic minorities able to sit as members of the House.“Racism is a sin,” they said. “There is no place for it in the world and we are determined to make sure there is no room for it in the Church.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: covid reaches everest base camp climbers infected
story: Nepal has reported its first cases of Covid-19 among climbers trying to conquer Everest, only weeks after the world's highest mountain reopened with strict public health precautions.Several climbers have tested positive for coronavirus infection in the capital, Kathmandu, after being flown from the mountain's base camp, the New York Times reported.The infections could be a blow for hopes of a revival to Nepal's lucrative mountain tourism industry, after it was devastated by lockdowns in 2020.Climbers were welcomed back last month after local officials said they would institute a strict regime of testing and social distancing for those attempting the 29,032 ft peak.Yet mountaineering blogs have reported some expeditions are disregarding the rules, with climbers failing to wear masks or keep their distances while at base camp waiting to begin their ascents.Prativa Pandey, medical director at the CIWEC Hospital which has identified the infections said officials at base camp were trying to stop climbers from mingling with one another.“We are taking it up with the health ministry to see what we can do for the safety of climbers and staff up there,” Dr Pandey told the paper.Climbers have had to show negative test results on arrival and quarantine themselves. They have also reportedly had to take on extra insurance this year.“We have no other options,” Rudra Singh Tamang, the head of Nepal’s tourism department, said earlier this month “We need to save the mountaineering economy.”The first victim was thought to be suffering from altitude sickness last week when they were air lifted from base camp back to Kathmandu. But testing showed they were infected by coronavirus.As in neighbouring India, Nepal had hoped it had seen off the worst of the pandemic and cases had fallen sharply from a peak last autumn. The daily infection tally has begun to rise quickly in recent weeks though. The country has recorded nearly 300,000 cases and around 3,000 deaths. Nepal began is vaccination campaign in January with AstraZeneca vaccines provided by India but suspended it last month following lack of supply.The base camp flare-up could jeopardise further attempts to reach the top. “Certainly, everybody agrees that a Covid outbreak in Everest Base Camp would spell the end of the season,” wrote Angela Benavides on the Explorersweb site.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Learner drivers have been unable to book driving tests since December  due to the coronavirus pandemic.But luckily, driving tests will resume from today, April , in England and Wales – but those in Scotland will have to wait a bit longer. Driving lessons resumed in England and Wales on April , and demand for tests has skyrocketed. Most test centres are working through a backlog of thousand, but the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agencysaid it was doing “all we can to provide as many tests as possible to help clear the backlog as quickly as we can”. If you are lucky enough to have bagged yourself a test, you may be wondering what changes have been made. Are you facing a long wait to sit your test because of Covid restrictions  Get in touch: emma.munbodh@mirror Here we explain how to book a test, and all the rules you need to be aware ofyou have a test coming up. How to book a driving test You can book a practical driving test for:cars motorcycles lorries, buses and coaches approved driving instructorpart  and  test This can be done online on the government website using the service which is available from am to .pm.You will need your UK driving licence number, credit card and driving instructor’’s personal reference number before you book a test. You can book a test for up to  weeks in the future, and there is no waiting list or cancellation list.Do I need to wear a face covering   You need to wear a face coveringyou are taking a driving test. Butyou have a reason for not wearing one, you must state this when booking. Your test can be cancelledyou attend your test without a face covering, and you didn’t give a good reason when booking it. When prompted for any special requirements, the government website says you should select “Special learning or educational needs”, evenyou can’t wear one for a physical reason. Say you can’t wear a face covering, and give your reason. Reasons for not wearing a face covering include:having a physical or mental illness or impairment, or a disability wearing it would cause you severe distressDo I need to take a Covid test   It is not mandatory to take a Covid- test before a driving test – you’ll still be allowed without one. However, the government is now recommending people who are taking driving tests having a rapid lateral flow test up to four days before – evenyou have no symptoms.Rapid lateral flow tests are now free, and you will get your result within  minutes. For more details check here.Rues for the car you use  You have to clean the inside of your car before your test. That means:tidying any unnecessary items away from the dashboard, footwells, door pockets, cup holders and seats wiping down the dashboard and car controlsThe examiner will also do an additional clean of some surfaces. The car you use for your test must also have at least one window open on each side thought the test.This can be a combination of windows – for example one front and one back. So make sure you wear suitable clothes for the weather.Other things to note about driving tests The government ask you don’t arrive for your test more than five minutes before your appointment time. Some driving test centre waiting rooms are closed, but toilets are available on request, evenwaiting rooms are closed. Driving examiners will wear face coverings, but they may also choose to wear gloves and use disposable seat covers. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  As a safety precaution your driving instructor or supervisor will not be allowed to sit in the back during your test. If you have a problem with your face covering during your test, your examiner will ask you to stop so you can adjust it. If this becomes a safety issue your driving examiner will end the test early. Reasons you shouldn’t attend your driving test

title: marcus rashford calls free school
story: NewsMarcus Rashford calls for free school meals guarantee over summer holidaysThe star footballer, who relied on free school meals as a child, said help in the summer would have made a massive, massive dference to his familymirrorShareCommentsByLizzy BuchanPolitical Correspondent:,  APR NewsFootballer Marcus Rashford said free school meals in the summer would have made a massive dference to his family " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeMarcus Rashford has called on ministers to guarantee free school meals continue over the summer holidays. The footballer, who forced Downing Street to u-turn on the issue last year, paved the way for a fresh battle over holiday hunger. Mr Rashford, who relied on free school meals as a child, said help in the summer would have made a “massive, massive dference” to his family. Vouchers were offered during lockdown school closures but ministers resisted calls to continue the £-a-week coupons last summer until Mr Rashford pressured them into a u-turn. The footballer also shamed the Government into offering support during the holidays in November through a Covid winter grant scheme given to councils. The scheme, renamed the Covid Local Support Grant, has now been extended until June  to help poorer families with food and bills outside of term time. The Government’s holiday activities and food programme was also boosted to cover Easter, summer and Christmas breaks this year.But Labour has warned that neither scheme guarantees free school meals for all needy families.More than , children have become eligible for free lunches since the first lockdown, taking the total to . million in October.The Manchester United star spoke of how his mum Melanie struggled during the holidays as he launched a new budget cooking campaign.Asked by The Mirror about free school meals, the top striker said: “I definitely think it needs to be extended and the reason why I say that is, I’m just going back to what it was like for me in the summers. “It’s much more dficult for my mum to keep on top of. Obviously in my household there were four children so as a single parent it was obviously tough for her. “But when we were all in school or in high school, she can rest a little bit because she knows that we’re having a meal there, and then potentially she only has to worry about one meal, which is dinner time. “So having free school meals throughout summer holidays for me would have made a massive, massive dference. “And I feel like what’s happened this year, like the pandemic, it’s affected everyone in dferent ways. “I just don’t see there being anything wrong with extending free school meals, like it’s going to do a lot more good than bad so I definitely think that that should happen.” Children’s Commissioner Rachel de Souza has also called for the scheme to be extended into the summer holidays.  Shadow Childrenaposs Minister Tulip Siddiq said: “Free school meals have been a leline for so many children in this pandemic. “Despite being shamed into action, the Government is still not guaranteeing free school meals over summer. In fact, Ministers’ are passing the buck onto local authorities and their guidance suggests children are provided with food support over just half of the summer holiday. “This simply isn’t good enough and could lead to a postcode lottery in food support.” A Government spokesperson said: “Our expanded Holiday Activities and Food programme, which provides healthy food and enriching activities to disadvantaged children, will run this summer in every local authority in England.Wider support is available including our increased Healthy Start scheme payments and we will continue to explore further options.” Mr Rashford is launching “Full Time: Get Cooking with Marcus and Tom” on Sunday alongside Michelin-starred chef Tom Kerridge. The duo will do weekly cooking tutorials on social media with celebrity pals like Fearne Cotton and Joe Wicks, using cheap and easy recipes, such as Mr Rashford’s favourite spaghetti bolognese.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBusiness Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng has defended as very good billionaire business leaders texting the Prime Minister directly. The top Tory welcomed the direct access the private sector had to ministers and Whitehall decision makers - despite it prompting allegations of cronyism. And he admitted he was contacted all the time by business people and constituents on his phone, despite holding one of the most sensitive portfolios. Labour has accused the Tories of operating government by Whatsapp with only those with links to senior ministers able to get access.Whitehall’s top civil servant is said to be concerned about how easily the PM can be contacted by text by lobbyists, MPs and business people. But Mr Johnson is reported to have rejected Cabinet Secretary Simon Case’s advice to change his mobile phone number, which he has had for more than a decade. The PM has a reputation for listening to the last person he has spoken to, leading to fears that he could be vulnerable to changing or adopting policy. Mr Kwarteng told Sky News: I think that in the real world, in reality, people are contacting ministers, contacting MPs, all the time. Business people are contacting MPs all the time, constituents also contact me on my phone. I think that in a modern democracy itaposs very good that people actually can have direct access to ministers and people who are taking responsibility.  It came as Mr Johnsonaposs ex-comms chief Lee Cain warned that without more working-class figures at the top of Government, ministers would be ever more baffled and out of touch with the electorate. Mr Kwarteng acknowledged there were issues around the Greensill Capital controversy, adding that while there is high standards in public le we can always try and make an improvement. He told LBC: I donapost think it is a drip-drip of sleaze. Clearly, we need to have very, very high standards in public le and I think there were issues around Greensill. I hasten to add that we have got about six committees looking at the Greensill issue.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA Brit couple who spent £, converting a massive American yellow school bus into a luxury home are now offering it up for sale in a raffle. Lucy Stevens, , and Glen Carloss, , bonded over their love of American cars on their first date and even spoke about a shared dream of converting a big bus. Just a few months later they shipped the ft x ft yellow bus from New York to Southampton. It still contained kidsapos toys, discarded school jumpers and sick notes, and they spent nearly a year converting it into a mobile home. Out came the seats and in went heating, a cinema room, a bathroom, a fireplace and a king size bed - but crucially the iconic yellow exterior remains untouched. Videos show their entire process - and the months of blood, sweat and tears that went into the transformation. Would you live in a bus  Share your thoughts in the comments below... Lucy, from Addlestone, Surrey, said: We both shared the same dream of owning a big vehicle to do a road trip for a year or longer. Iaposve always be obsessed with Grand Designs so to achieve something like that, to totally transform something into a liveable home for someone, itaposs mad. We worked so hard on it, itaposs been blood, sweat and tears just because weaposd never taken on anything like that before.  How we achieved the look we wanted to achieve, Iaposm really proud of it. Lucy, a nanny, went on her first date to a rooftop bar in Southbank, London, with tattoo artist Glen in July of , and they quickly discovered they had a lot in common. She said: I told him about my dream of having an American school bus. Glen already had a passion for American cars.  It was absolutely mental, I thought he was joking - we both had the same dream! So, a few months after that first date we started looking into getting one. They found a company who helped ship the iconic buses from the States, and after one look at their yard, the pair paid £, to get their very own in November .  The bus arrived in Southampton four months later in its original condition - with pupilsapos names scribbled on seats and toys, hair bands, and handwritten sick notes strewn inside. Lucy said: It was mind-blowing to see it in person and to think about its previous use, and what we were about to turn it into. And it was huge, itaposs so much more daunting in real le but I absolutely loved it, I couldnapost actually believe I owned it.  The couple got to work with a full renovation - tearing out the seats and flooring before installing electrics, plumbing and heating and partitioning off the bathroom and bedroom. They spent another £, turning the old bus into a liveable space - the only one like it in the UK, they said. They added a king-sized bed, sofa bed, dining area, compostable toilet, indoor shower, fridge, hob, oven, work desk and garage space for outdoor equipment. The transformed vehicle also boasts a cinema room with a projector, as well as a a king-size bed, shower and electric fireplace.

title: dad left crying hysterically after
story: NewsDad left crying hysterically after teenagers stole family car with sons,  and , insideThe teenagers, who were  at the time of the incident, said they did not notice the children in the back of the car which they stole from the Selly Park area of Birmingham before crashing itmirrorShareByMatthew CooperDigital Sports ReporterMilo BoydReporter:,  APR NewsThe car was stolen from the Selly Park area of Birmingham" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA dad was left crying hysterically in the street when his two children where kidnapped by two teenagers who stole his car and crashed it. Two youths, who were both  at the time, claimed they did not notice the two and four-year-old children in the back of the car when they stole it with its engine running from Selly Park area of Birmingham. One of the boys told Birmingham Magistratesapos Court how he crashed into two other cars at high speed, before being arrested by armed police. Although the older child was uninjured in the crash, the two-year-old suffered a cut to his mouth and a bruised shoulder caused by the straps of his car seat. The driver, who is still , claimed he took the vehicle to settle a £ drug debt, after mistaking the dad for a delivery driver. He insisted he did not realise the siblings had been strapped into the rear of the Nissan Note until police arrested him on suspicion of kidnap. But District Judge Shamim Qureshi accepted the evidence of the boysapos father, who told the court he shouted to alert the youths to the fact his sons were inside the vehicle minutes before the crash on Birminghamaposs busy A Bristol Road. Finding both defendants guilty of two counts of kidnap, Judge Qureshi said: The only issue in this case is whether the defendants took the children without lawful authority or reasonable excuse. Their defence in this case is that they were unaware that the two children were in the car. Ruling that the younger youth had decided to steal the Nissan and the other boy went along with the theft, the judge said common sense meant the children would not have remained quiet during the entire journey. Both defendants admitted aggravated vehicle taking, incorporating dangerous driving, at a previous hearing, but had denied kidnap. The court heard the childrenaposs father was left crying hysterically in the street after his vehicle was stolen on Saturday, February . Giving evidence as his mother watched from the public gallery, the boy who drove the car told the court he was equipped with bolt cutters and looking for a bicycle to steal when he saw the Nissan with its engine running. Claiming his intention was to sell the car to pay off a debt, the teenager said he crashed after being pursued by a police van and seeing oncoming police cars. Describing the moment of impact, the -year-old went on: I apossandwichedapos the car between two other cars and then ran off. title: dispelling common myth around grief
story: AdvertorialDispelling the common myth around grief, and other advice from bereavement expertsWe teamed up with Co-op Funeralcare to learn how to better support ourselves and others after losing loved onesmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  APR Updated:,  APR AdvertorialWhile grief is a natural process, its effects can be overwhelming and devastating at the best of times, and even harder for many who have had to grieve alone as a result of the past year.The Mirror partnered with Co-op Funeralcare to bring together a  of experts to talk about dealing with grief in a special Facebook Live event to help support others cope with bereavement.Andy Langford, Clinical Director at Cruse Bereavement Care, has worked in bereavement services for the last  years and is experienced in supporting people who have lost loved ones. Meanwhile, Carina White is co-founder and host of Black Mums Upfront - an honest and frank podcast about modern-day motherhood, touching on subjects that can be hard to talk about, including death and the experience of losing loved ones.Finally, Helen Chandler is Head of Operations for Co-op Funeralcare, who are committed to supporting people before, during and after the funeral.Everyoneaposs grief is dferent All the experts agree that thereaposs no one-size-fits-all solution for coping with grief. Every experience is unique, and everyoneaposs emotional and physical symptoms are dferent. If we prepare ourselves and talk about this more, we will be more prepared to support ourselves but also to support our loved ones as well, says Carina.  How to REALLY listen to someone whoaposs grieving Supporting a friend through their grief is important - but itaposs often hard to know how. Sometimes saying nothing at all and simply listening is the best approach, according to the experts. What it does is show the bereaved person that the relationship they have with the person who has died really, really matters, Andy explains.  How has the pandemic changed the way we grieve  Itaposs unlikely weaposll know the full effects of the past yearaposs events on bereavement, but it has certainly had an impact. People have been hugely imaginative in terms of the types of services theyaposve arranged, reveals Helen. Lots of families have said that they would be having a memorial service or some kind of event in the future when hopefully the pandemic is over and we are free to move on and that tells me something really important. Those families certainly donapost intend for their grief journeys to be over.

title: dozens diners leave without paying
story: NewsDozens of diners leave without paying for meals at the Dorchester after fire alarmA patio fire at the Dorchesters rooftop restaurant meant all  customers had to be evacuated onto the street, with most then leaving without footing their billsmirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  APR NewsDiners at the Dorchester did a runner without paying, it has been reported " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA fire alarm at a five-star London hotel gave dozens of diners the chance to leave without paying for their meals, losing the venue thousands of pounds. The Dorchester in Mayfair had to evacuate all  customers from its rooftop restaurant The Grill at .pm last Friday after a patio heater caught fire. By the time firefighters arrived on the scene it had already been put out, said London Fire Brigade. However, during the commotion it gave almost all the punters chance to slip away into the night without covering their bills at a cost of around £,, it has been claimed.A source told The Sun: The whole thing was a complete carry on. Did you witness this incident  Let us know at webnews@mirrorThe fire brigade were called when a gas heater burst into flames but whoever rang told them a person was on fire so they sent ambulances and the fire brigade. Once it was clear they realised that guests had left without paying any of their bills. Hotel management told the newspaper the money lost will have to be written off, though said all guests had been contacted the following day. The famed eatery boasts a menu by TV chef Tom Booton which includes portions of chips for £, a prawn scotch egg starter for £ and a £ lemon tart. Champagne, meanwhile, starts at £ a glass. The hotel said no one was hurt in the “minor incident”.

title: duty kate middleton spotted taking
story: NewsOff-duty Kate Middleton spotted taking George, Charlotte and Louis stationery shoppingKate Middleton gave Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis a budget to buy some new stationery ready to go back to schoolmirrorShareCommentsByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsKate took her children out shopping" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Duchess of Cambridge was spotted treating her children Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis to some fun new stationery during a family shopping trip. Kate and her royal trio popped into Smiggle on Kingaposs Road in London on Monday, ahead of the older Cambridge kidsto school yesterday after the Easter Holidays. Fellow shoppers claim that the children were given their own budget in the shop, and once they had picked their items took them to the till and paid with their own money. Twitter user @lex wrote: Just normal well brought up children and a normal parent trying to do the right thing and that’s just lovely!Itaposs far from the first time Kate has been seen popping to the shops with her children. In  she was seen buying Halloween costumes for George and Charlotte in Sainsburyaposs, using the self-check out tills at the Norfolk supermarket. The year before, shoppers were stunned to see the family in The Range, and George was fascinated by a pot of slime. Teacher Sarah Daniels told Daily Mail : As I was looking at the shelves I noticed a tall dark-haired lady further down the aisle and thought to myself ‘I recognise that face’.Mrs Daniels said that at one point, Charlotte sat on the floor and was told by her mother, dressed casually in jeans, low-heeled boots and a jacket: Get up, poppet. George then askedthey could buy some dinosaur slime – a popular school playground fad in Britain – but Mrs Daniels said she didn’t register a response from the Prince’s mother.  She added that when she left The Range a fleet of Range Rovers were parked outside. Mrs Daniels presumed they had transported the royals and their police protection officers to the store.Mondayaposs stationary shopping trip came two days after Kate joined other members of the royal family to say their final goodbyes to Prince Philip at his funeral over the weekend.Kate looked emotional as she sat at her husband Prince Williamaposs side for the service in St Georgeaposs Chapel.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAn amazing young man stepped in covered the cost after four customers fled a pub without paying their large food bill. Landlords Sarah and Andy House were left out of pocket after the scammers targeted the Kings Arms in Elham, Kent, just days after pubs were allowed to reopen their beer gardens.Like other publicans they had been shut for months because of the coronavirus pandemic, until April  where they were able to serve food and drink to punters outside. The couple confessed it had been frantic coming up with a new way of operating and were suddenly liable for full rent payments, reports Kent Live.The challenge didnapost get any easier when a table of four left with without paying a penny of their bill on their first Saturday after reopening.Are you a pub landlord who has suffered an increase in people fleeing without paying since reopening  Email webnews@mirror Sarah was so incensed she took to Facebook to call them out.Her post read: Thank you to the table of four, booked in under the name of Josh, who took up a reserved table that we turned customers away from as standing room only. You were  minutes late, keeping the kitchen staff on, you received excellent service, food and drinks, however we will put your leaving very quickly before settling your £ bill down as an oversight, because we are decent people working hard to earn a living, oh and you left in such a hurry you might want to come back and pick your cigarettes up. The post sparked a deluge of support, with people calling the behaviour utterly disgusting to good hard working good people after a dficult year due to the lockdown.  To make matters worse, the table in question were not the only customers to walk away that week without paying. This meant Sarah and Andy were forced to keep peopleaposs bank cards as deposits when they take their table. Liam Jenner, a -year-old who lives in nearby Folkestone and used to work with Sarah at the council, spotted the post and decided to act. He went straight down to the pub and discreetly left £ in an envelope behind the bar. KentLive tracked Liam down after getting his details from Sarah.He said: Sarah used to be my manager at the council a few years back so I’ve known her for a while and often travel to the pub to help her out by buying meals and drinks. I just thought it was very unfair that after such a struggle for pubs during the last year or so with COVID and lockdown that people could do such a thing to struggling businesses. So I thought her business could probably do with the money a lot more than I needed it right now.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Britainaposs youngest EuroMillions winner has undergone a second bum lt operation after her original procedure saw her rushed to hospital with suspected sepsis. Jane Park - who won £million when she was just  - has revealed to her more than , Instagram followers she flew to a private clinic in Turkey earlier this month to have the op redone.The now -year-old, from Edinburgh, travelled to the Trio Clinic in Istanbul, adding that she canapost wait for the swelling to go down so she can show off the results. In , a botched job at another clinic in Turkey led to a severe infection and she later admitted she feared she was going to die, claimingshe had known the risks she never would have agreed to the procedure. She warned other young women not to have the surgery, despite it being popular with celebrities and influencers. After her win, Jane has spent more than £, on ious cosmetic surgeries, including breast implants. In her IG post she said: Surgery isnapost always an easy decision, I have had liposuction and BBLredone . Canapost wait til the swelling goes down and I can see my full results.  Before the op, she posted: “Just so everyone knows and itaposs came from me I will be having surgery in the next week. “I will share it all every detail from start till finish once I have woke up and Iaposm recovering. Feel like it has to come from me. All will be revealed in due course.” During an appearance on ITVaposs This Morning in , Jane described the botched procedure, which left her truly swollen from head to toe, to the point where she could barely open her eyes.  I literally thought that I was going to die. I donapost know what was wrong with me and they said to me Iaposd had a reaction to the anaesthetic, she said. Jane went on to criticise the aftercare she received, and said despite being in a lot of pain she was told Youaposve paid for the surgery. If I knew that was going to happen and I would have had the problems I had with it, I would never have done it, she had told the programme.

title: lucky fisherman catches rare 1
story: NewsLucky fisherman catches rare  in  million blue lobster off Cornish coastTom Lambourn is only in his second season of fishing and couldnt believe his luck when he pulled in a bright blue lobster. After taking photos of the catch, he put it back in the seamirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  APR NewsThe chances of catching a blue lobster are one in two million, according to experts " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA fisherman caught an exceptionally rare one in two million bright blue lobster off the Cornish coast. Tom Lambourn was stunned when he opened his lobster pot aboard boat aposMy Lassapos to find the vivid crustacean inside while commercial fishing off Penzance, Cornwall. The -year-old, from Newlyn, photographed the ins European lobster, Latin name Homarus gammarus, before letting it go as it was too small to take home. Blue lobsters get this colour because of a genetic abnormality which causes an over-production of the protein crustacyanin. Fishermen who come across one believe it to be a sign of good luck and usually do not eat it. Lobsters are generally brown or grey in colour, providing camouflage against the rocky sea bed.Have you made a rare catch to rival Tomaposs  Let us know at webnews@mirrorJust like all lobsters, the blue lobster will turn bright red when cooked. Tom said: With every pot you never know what is going to be inside, and Iaposve certainly never seen one that colour before. This is only my second fishing season so I think Iaposve been very lucky. I measured it and it was undersized so there was never any thought of keeping it. If it had been bigger, I would have taken it to the National Hatchery.  I sent them some photos of the lobster and they told me it is one in two million so that is quite special. A spokesman for National Lobster Hatchery in Padstow, Cornwall, said: It is a pretty rare colour morph to come across, about one in two million chance, so we were amazed when Tom sent us the photo of it. The lobster was too small to bring in to land so was popped back in the sea so it can keep growing. Who knew that a crustacean could be so vibrant

title: make testing habit prevent spread
story: AdvertorialMake testing a habit to prevent the spread of Covid-Guidelines are changing and people are starting to be able to see friends and family outside - but before you do, read thismirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  APR Updated:,  APR AdvertorialRegular testing will help stop the virus spreadingWith restrictions easing and more people getting vaccinated against Covid- every day, the UK is making careful progress to get back towards some form of normality. Of course, that doesnapost mean the risk of catching and spreading the virus is over. Around one in three people with Covid- have no symptoms and could be spreading it without knowing. That’s why rapid lateral flow tests are now available for everyone with no symptoms. Millions of people are taking part in regular, rapid testing twice a week - at work,thataposs an option, or at a test site or at home.Regular rapid testing is a fast and easy way for you to find outyou have coronavirus - and by building this habit of testing twice a week into your le, you can help stop the virus spreading.Based on the same trusted technology as a pregnancy test, the tests to detect Covid- are easy, and carried out in the following four stages.

title: miracle baby born after 8
story: NewsMiracle baby born after  miscarriages has hair so thick shes mistaken for toddlerLottie Batchelor has been branded a "miracle baby" as her mum had eight miscarriages before her- she has now has gone viral due because of a head of hair so thick people think shes twomirrorShareCommentsByCally Brooks:,  APR NewsLittle Lottie Batchelor was born with a head of hair so thick people mistake her for a toddler " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA miracle baby born after eight miscarriages was born with a head of hair so thick that people think sheaposs a toddler. Little Lottie Batchelor, who has just turned one, shocked her parents Emily, , and Matthew, , when she was born with thick black hair that grew to  inches in a year.Her mum said she didnapost suffer a heartburn, which is what many would think could be the cause for her baby having so much hair.But she did speak of how she is a miracle baby, as she and Matthew had tried to have a child but had eight miscarriages. They were told they werenapost going to be able to conceive naturally, but then they miraculously fell pregnant with Lottie. Mum Emily has to use an abundance of hair products to keep Lottieaposs locks tamed - including conditioner, anti frizz serum, detangler, curl serum, and curl spray. The full time mum also has to style Lottieaposs hair every morning - adding an extra  minutes onto her morning routine. Now Lottieaposs hair is almost the sameas her six-year-old sisteraposs Evie - with many thinking the one-year-old is a lot older than she actually is. Mum Emily explained: When she was born, I was surprised by how dark her hair was and how much of it there was - I wasnapost expecting it at all.  Her hair was the first thing people would notice when they met her people were always commenting on her hair saying how lucky she was to have so much. Sheaposs never lost any - itaposs just got thicker and thicker. Now, her hair goes half way down her back when itaposs wet and by the time sheaposs two, I think itaposll be the sameas Evieaposs. People are shocked when I say that Lottie is only -months-old - most people think sheaposs at least two! I have to use conditioner because it gets so frizzy and it takes longer to blow dry her hair than my eldest. It takes about half an hour to dry and  minutes to style in the morning I have to put her fringe up everyday to get it out of the way and I make sure to brush it through.  If I donapost take the time to do it in the morning, itaposll be matted by the end of the day. Itaposs very time consuming - she has better hair products and more than me! Despite Evie being born with dark hair, parents Emily and Matthew, who works as a builder, were not expecting the amount of hair little Lottie was born with. Emily added: Evie was born with dark hair but it was nothing like Lottieaposs so we werenapost expecting it at all.  I had dark hair when I was born and so did my husband but again, it was nothing like Lottieaposs. Sheaposs very lucky to have it and I wish that I had her hair! Lottieaposs hair is gradually getting a bit lighter so we think sheaposll be blonde in the next year or so.Emily posted the picture on Facebook group Family Lockdown Tips and Ideas and received an overwhelming response.

title: paedo jeffrey epsteins pleasure palace
story: NewsPaedo Jeffrey Epsteins pleasure palace where Prince Andrew visited wiped off mapJeffrey Epstein and Prince Andrews alleged pleasure palace has been wiped off the map as a £.million buyer sends in a digger to ensure no trace is leftmirrorShareByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThe Mirrors Christopher Bucktin outside the mansion " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe mansion of pervert Jeffrey Epstein, where his pal Prince Andrew allegedly “spent weeks” with him surrounded by topless teens, has been demolished. Epstein abused underage girls at the house, which was adorned with pictures of naked girls and stocked with sex toys. Developer Todd Michael Glaser, who bought it for £.million, sent in a digger to ensure no trace was left. Estate agent Lawrence Moens said: “I only got involved in the sale to ensure it would be wiped off the map.”  One neighbour near the waterside property in Palm Beach, Florida, said: “Good riddance.That sick b****** abused dozens of girls in that home.Thank God it’s gone.” Remnants of Epstein’s grotesque lestyle could be seen in the debris as the Mirror visited the site. It was here that victims said his alleged “madam” Ghislaine Maxwell, a pal of the prince, would help recruit girls and schedule teenagers to give Epstein massages. Maxwell was held by the FBI last year but denies any involvement in grooming minors for her late ex Epstein. Former butler Juan Alessi swore on oath in a  criminal probe that he set up massage tables for Andrew, , every day as the royal “spent weeks with us” at the house. He recalled seeing naked girls by the pool during Andrew’s stay but said they dressed before entering the house. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeLe behind-the-scenes at the Palace has been much calmer since Prince Harry and Meghan Markle quit, a source has claimed. The Sussexes walked away from their senior royal roles in March last year in favour of a new le in LA with their son, Archie. This, along with the Queen sacking Prince Andrew over his relationship with Jeffery Epstein, left The Firm without three working royals - with Prince Edward and Sophie Wessex stepping up to help out. Prince Charles is working out the logistics of how things will look going forward, and has the job of carving up future engagements, projects and royal tours. As a way of supporting the Queen, the family have scheduled a meeting to sort out future business of the monarchy and design tailor made roles for each of the seven senior members of The Firm. It will include collaboration and support for one another from the Prince of Wales, Duchess of Cornwall, Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, Princess Anne and the Earl and Countess of Wessex. Despite the smaller team, a source said that things are calmer without Meghan and Harry. Keep up to date with the latest royal news with our daily royal newsletter. Click here to find out more.  A source said: “One of the main issues with Harry and Meghan when they were part of the working family was their inability to understand how things worked. It’s been a lot simpler without them kicking off over why they couldn’t just do what they wanted. “Things are a lot calmer.” Sophie Wessex, who has been described as the royal familyaposs secret weapon, will take on an increased public role going forward.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice The safest areas of England have emerged with more than one in  areas recording fewer than  coronavirus cases in the space of a week, new figures show.The numbers show  spots have seen new case numbers tumble to just a handful even in the week that pubs, shops and gyms reopened. Among them are natural beauty spots, including coastal Devon district of South Hams - which recorded just two new cases in the week to Friday - along with Chiltern in Buckinghamshire, Rother in East Sussex, and the Forest of Dean, which recorded three confirmed infections each. More than half of all UK adults have now received at least one dose of a vaccine, with more than million recorded as having received a jab by Wednesday.Scroll down to see the full list...The number of areas recording spikes in infection rates is also tapering off, with even the highest infection rates now less than  cases per , people in every area of England. The figures, for the seven days to April , are based on the number of people who have tested positive for Covid- in either a lab-reported or rapid lateral flow test, by specimen date. The numbers include the first week of Englandaposs lockdown easing which saw hospitality and retail reopen on Monday, April . However it must be noted experts have previously warned the virus can take days to show symptoms or to trigger a positive test result, with any potential changes in case numbers linked to the easing of restrictions likely yet to be fully documented. Authorities are also closely monitoring the arrival of a new India iant of the virus which has arrived on UK shores, with more than  cases recorded. The fresh strain prompted the Government to add India to its aposred listapos of countries under strict travel limitations. title: uk weather brits soak up
story: NewsUK weather: Brits to soak up the sun with C temperatures and heatwave on wayWarm air is predicted to sweep across Northern Europe and the UK at the start of next month but there will be plenty of sun until the scorching heat spike arrivesmirrorShareCommentsBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsAfter a milder Wednesday, it will feel warmed over the next few days " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeTemperatures are expected toto C on Thursday but within weeks we could be baking in sweltering C conditions. Many Brits will soak up the sun despite a frosty start to the day making for another cold morning. It will be warmest in the east of England today, with the south expected to be breezy. But we could see temperatures soon double with a heat-wave set to arrive inside two weeks. The mercury could be set to hit C, meaning it could be a scorcher over the May Bank Holiday. Climate pattern La Nina will play a large part in the sudden spike. Warm air is predicted to sweep across Northern Europe and the UK at the start of next month.Meteorologist Jim Dale claims some very warm weather is in front of us.“There will definitely be some spikes of heat as we go into summer when I expect to see temperatures in the high Cs or even the low Cs, the British Weather Services expert said. “This is largely because of a balancing effect which, after the colder period of weather over the past couple of months, dominated by a northerly airflow, should revert and come from a more southerly direction. “This will bring more in the way of hotter weather as we go through the end of spring and into summer. “This summer could be up there with the warmer ones from the past ten years, it is more likely to turn out one of the warmer ones that to be cooler.” Friday will be dry with lots of sunshine expected, and just some patchy fair-weather cloud.  A nice weekend is forecast across England and Wales, with cloud in some parts of Scotland.Until the temperatures soar, the Met Office says we should expect chilly evenings, with frost possible.UK Weather Forecast Today: A cold start, but dry and sunny weather follow. The east will see the best of the weather, and it will be breezy in the south.
