title: jcb-potholepro-scottish-borders-council-trials-new-machine
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas been trying out a new machine which claims to fix potholes four times quicker than normal ndash and at half the cost.The PotholePro, launched by JCB, is a three-in-one machine acting as a planer, cropper and cleaner.SBC gave it a trial todayand yesterday, with councillor Gordon Edgar witnessing the results.Mr Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, told the Border : "Its an effective piece of kit ndash Im quite pleased with the operation.":Cycle lanes proposed for Borders town to boost safety and encourage exerciseThe PotholePro could replace four pieces of equipment currently used to temporarily fix potholes.Ben Rawding, from the JCB Product Team, said: "The Pothole Pro fixes potholes four times quicker and is half the cost of current machines. On average it costs pound per pothole, [but] we cost pound."In the last year, SBC has temporarily repaired around , potholes in the region."No pothole is the same," Mr Edgar said. "We have a project of repairs which costs up to pound. million over a year."The Borders has been trialling the new JCB PotholePro. Photo: Helen BarringtonWhile current repairs to potholes on Borders roads are temporary, JCBrsquos Mr Rawding says the PotholePro offers a permanent solution which gets to the root of the problem.He said: "If you go to the dentist with a cavity, they wont fill it straight away, they remove the decay and then fill in."Thats what were doing here, removing the decaying road so it can be filled in."According to Mr Rawding, the average time it takes for the PotholePro to clear a large pothole is eight minutes, compared with  minutes per pothole by other means.:Ive got big plans: Peeblesshire vet elected to senior role in Young FarmersHe added that the machine is able to clear  potholes a day, whereas current methods could see  or  cleared.Meanwhile, Mr Edgar said that although the PotholePro replaces four pieces of equipment, this would be unlikely to affect road workers."We would have dedicated teams, he said. "Wed have to restructure the team we have now to work with the equipment."We can get more work done with the machine and in experienced hands save the council money."The council only had the PotholePro for two days, but there is scope to extend the trial period.To see the PotholePro in action, visit our Facebookpage to see live videos captured today on the A near St Boswells.

title: attainment-gap-borders-schools-worst-nation-says-report
story: THE attainment gap between the most and least deprived Borders pupils is wider than in any other council area in Scotland, according to a report.The report, entitled lsquoImproving outcomes for young people through school educationrsquo, was published in March by Audit Scotland.Scottish Borders Council says it ldquoremains committed to closing the attainment gap between the most and least deprived pupils following the reportrsquos findings.Exhibit  of the report shows the percentage of school leavers who achieved five or more awards at SCQF Level  [National ] in  .The graph shows that . per cent of the lsquomost deprivedrsquo pupils achieved this feat, compared with . per cent of pupils classed as lsquoleast deprivedrsquo.That gives the Borders a . per cent dference between the two categories ndash the biggest gap in Scotland.:Borders tries out new machine meant to fix potholes super fast and at lower costA Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoThis is just a single measure, and only looks at the number of pupils attaining five SQA Level  awards.ldquoScottish Borders Councilrsquos performance has improved across a number of other areas, and of course the number of SQA awards should not be the only measure of the success of our young people.ldquoThe council remains committed to closing the attainment gap through a range of interventions and looks forward to receiving the next allocation from the Attainment Scotland Fund to help our schools tackle this issue.Other data displayed in the report shows that . per cent of school leavers in the Borders achieved one or more at SCQF Level  or better ndash a . per cent increase since  .The Borders also recorded . per cent achieving five awards or more at SCQF Level  or better ndash up . per cent on  .The report shows that more - year olds are participating in education, employment or training.:Ive got big plans: Peeblesshire vet elected to senior role in Young FarmersAudit Scotland concluded that progress on closing the attainment gap has been ldquolimited, with the dference between the least deprived and most deprived pupils ldquoevident at a local level, with some councils reporting much bigger gaps than others.The report states: ldquoThe poverty-related attainment gap remains wide and inequalities have been exacerbated by COVID-.ldquoProgress on closing the gap has been limited and falls short of the Scottish Governmentrsquos aims.ldquoImprovement needs to happen more quickly and there needs to be greater consistency across the country.A personrsquos level of deprivation, used to categorise pupils, is based on SIMD quintiles.:Timeline: When public services in the Borders will open ndash gyms, libraries, etcAn inidualrsquos SIMD status is based on where they live, ldquowith those who live in the  per cent of areas with the highest deprivation recorded as being in the most deprived quintile.Stephen Boyle, auditor general for Scotland, said: ldquoSignicantly reducing the attainment gap is complex."But the pace of improvement has to increase as part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos COVID- recovery planning.ldquoThat process needs to particularly focus on the pandemicrsquos impact on the most disadvantaged children and young people.

title: endometriosis-bex-leighs-borders-raffle-raises-thousands
story: A BORDERS woman has raised more than pound, for a national charity.Throughout March, Melrose business owner Bex Leigh ran a raffle with more than  prizes and raised awareness of endometriosis.Bex, , of Lauder, who has the condition herself, raised pound, for Endometriosis UK with the help of her mum Katy.Bex told the Border Telegraph: ldquoIrsquom just so grateful.The winners were selected on March .:Borders woman, , sets up region-wide raffle to raise awareness of diseaseldquoBefore we knew it, a couple [of] hours before the draw we hit poundk, and then just a few seconds before the draw, which was really late at night, we hit pound,, said Bex.ldquoIt was just crazy to watch. I was just sitting refreshing the button thinking, lsquoHow is this happeningrsquo The pound, was raised from the sale of raffle tickets, but Bex also received further donations directly to her fundraising page and in cash.Bex, who owns Bexleigh Beauty, added: ldquoIt was just so nice how many people wanted to learn about [endometriosis].ldquoIt [fundraising] gave me an insight into just how much I enjoy that side of work.:The Borders woman battling through pain to help others with common conditionAs well as the raffle, with the help of artist Judith Hardie, Bex and her mum hid  painted stones on popular walks for people to find.Bex said the Yellow Stone Trail was a great way for people to find out more about endometriosis.Looking to the future, Bex hopes to continue fundraising, but says she may need a few extra helping hands."I definitely would love to [fundraise again], but because it got so big, and of course because I struggle myself [with endometriosis] it did become quite a lot to take on," she said.

title: carham-hall-historic-mansion-near-borders-torn
story: AN HISTORIC mansion near the Borders is set to be demolished.Northumberlands Carham Hall, five miles from Coldstream, occupies the site of a th century tower house built to defend against the Border Reivers.The property was converted into a mansion house in the mid-th century, before being redeveloped in  into a Neo-Tudor style.Most recently a care home, Carham Hall is now set to be knocked down in September, with plans having been lodged with Northumberland County Council.:Borders tries out new machine meant to fix potholes super fast and at lower costThe building is not currently listed meaning its history and heritage face being lost.Yet a spokesperson from Historic England said: ldquoCarham Hall, Northumberland, is currently being considered for listing.This listing may prove the only way to save the property which has great historical signicance to the local area.The Victorian Society, a charity set up to protect Victorian and Edwardian buildings, said: "We are concerned about the loss of Carham Hall, a key local heritage asset.:Cycle lanes proposed for Borders town to boost safety and encourage exercise"The building is currently under threat as the owner plans to demolish the vacant building entirely.ldquoSadly, this is permitted development and no permission from the local authority is required.ldquoThe law on permitted development urgently needs reform. In a climate emergency, it is bizarre to demolish a high-quality building and waste all its embodied carbon.ldquoWe urge the owner to think again. If someone would be interested in reusing the building, please get in touch.:Borders schools rank worst in Scotland for pupil attainment gap, report showsIn recent times the house has been the site of a care home, but it has lain empty since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic in March .The planning application revealed the pound,-per-month running costs to be a major factor in the decision to demolish. The application also said signicant levels of asbestos had been found.Conservative councillor Anthony Murray, who represents Wooler, said: ldquoI have looked at all the ways it is possible for the County to object to the demolition but unfortunately none are possible. I am afraid it appears that demolition will go ahead.A Northumberland County Council spokesperson said: "As Carham Hall isnt listed or in a defined Conservation Area, the council was bound by national legislation and could only look at amenity issues in terms of demolition such as potential levels of noise and dust."It has no powers to prevent a developer from demolishing the building.

title: peebles-cycle-lanes-idea-debated-towns-community-council
story: PROPOSALS to introduce cycle lanes in a Borders townwere criticised at a community council meeting last week.Scottish Borders Councilcame under fire from Peebles Community Council chairman Les Turnbull,who said members of the public are effectively being pushed to complete a public consultation with very little time to consider their views.Community council member Malcolm Bruce added: ldquoThe whole thing is an utter abomination of a plan.It was revealed that the proposals are part of the funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos lsquoSpaces for Peoplersquo scheme to make Peeblesrsquo High Street a more appealing place to walk and cycle ndash but the cash needs to be spent by the end of May.The online consultation, which began last Friday and ends on April , details plans to remove the white lines in the middle of the road to allow a six-month trial of advisory cycle lanesto give cyclists a more defined space.These would be introduced from the entry to Peebles on the Aalong High Street, over Tweed Bridge and along Kingsmeadows Road to Cavalry Park.Mr Turnbull said: ldquoI am concerned that SBC officers are trying to push us with a public consultation with the probable implementation of the scheme in early May.ldquoWhat concerns me is it seems to be another policy decision being made by officers without any consultation with those itrsquos going to affect, the residents of the town.Mr Turnbull said encouraging walking and cycling is ldquoadmirable, but called for a halt to the consultation.He added: ldquoI donrsquot think that trying to rush through these cycle lanes now in the way that itrsquos being done is the right way to do it. I know therersquos pressure on the officers because they want to apply for government money to implement this, but this is the wrong way round.Community councillor Graham Mackie said cycle lanes are a ldquocrazy idea at the moment.He said: ldquoMoving the bus stops from the high street to the car park is being considered, and this would be a huge change and might free up additional parking spaces, so it seems crazy to plan to do this now and then it might be obsolete in a few monthsrsquo time."It would make much more sense to delay it until a decision is made about where the buses are going to stop.SBC leader Shona Haslam said that when the council received the funding for the mph limits, the possibility of introducing cycle lanes was discussed.She added: ldquoThe issue is that we have the funding and the Scottish Government said that we have to spend this money by the end of May otherwise we lose it.ldquoIf we donrsquot do the cycle lanes now, we wonrsquot have any money to do them in the future.Mr Turnbull replied: ldquoThanks for the clarity around the funding, butthe plan is the wrong plan then we shouldnrsquot be spending the money on it, itrsquos as simple as that.But Mrs Haslam warned that SBC would forfeit the funding and said there will not be any capacity in the budget to have cycle lanes in the future.Responding, community councillor Elizabeth Rae said: ldquoLose the money, we donrsquot want it. If thatrsquos the only thing on which the money can be spent, lose the money.This was backed up by another community representative, Mr Bruce, who said: ldquoI hate having a gun put to my head like this."I do get on my bike occasionally, and I can tell you right now, I would be horried to cycle down those cycle lanes proposed on the high street ndash itrsquos just an accident waiting to happen.He added: ldquoIf they want to get folk on their bikes then you should be putting the money into cycle lanes well away from the main roads.Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell said: ldquoLet me be clear, this is a consultation, therersquos no policy decision being made, therersquos not a situation where the policy has been decided, this is a consultation on a proposal.

title: netflix-reveals-new-tv-series-films-coming-week
story: With so many streaming s includingNetflix, Amazon Prime, Disney+ and Now TV, we are spoiledfor choice when it comes to TV series and films.Although lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease, people will no doubt still be on the hunt for new TV show and films.Luckilyfor us, Netflix has us covered. The streaming giant has released a whole host of new shows and movies comingthis week.Here is the full list :April Luis Miguel ndash The SeriesNndash Next set of episodes in the Spanish biography series on the Mexican superstar.April Izzyrsquos Koala WorldNndash Kids live-action series.Smallfootndash Animated comedy about the elusive creature featuring the voices of Zendaya, James Corden and Channing Tatum.April ZeroNndash Italian superhero-drama series.April Searching for SheelaNndash Documentary on Ma Anand Sheela ing to India.StowawayNndash Sci-fi thriller starring Anna Kendrick and Toni Collette directed by Jon Penna.April Shadow and BoneNndash Based on the best-sellingGrishaversenovels by Leigh Bardugo, the fantasy-drama takes place in a world ravaged by war, where the threat of the Shadow Fold threatens to destroy everything.Unfortunately, as a number of new movies and TV shows come to Netflix, there will also be a lot of content removed this week.Netflix licenses a lot of its content which means a log of things on the streaming service are rented for a pre-specied number of months or years.Here is everything set to leave the  this week.Whatrsquos Leaving Netflix on April th Carol Club Friday To Be Continued ndash Friend  Enemy Club Friday To Be Continued ndash The Promise The Vatican Tapes Whatrsquos Leaving Netflix on April st The Last Resort Whatrsquos Leaving Netflix on April nd The Great British Baking Show: Masterclassndash Note:only the spin-off is leaving.Whatrsquos Leaving Netflix on April rd Disney ChannelrsquosLiv and MaddieWhatrsquos Leaving Netflix on April th Mirror Mirror Whatrsquos Leaving Netflix on April th Django Unchained

title: enduro-world-series-borders-event-could-bring-1-5m
story: A MAJOR event scheduled for the Borders could bring in pound. million for the area, according to council papers.Members of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive committee are due to meet on Tuesdayand will be asked to approve funding for the Enduro World Seriesmountain biking event.Thousands of people are expected to visit Innerleithen and Peebles for the event in the autumn.Council papers state that the biking spectacle could have an ldquoeconomic impact of pound.m for the area.:Outcry over bizarre plans to demolish historic mansion near the BordersldquoOne of the key events for the Tweed Valley over the next few years is the Enduro World Series , with the first event due to take place in October , the papers state.ldquoIt is anticipated,COVID- restrictions are relaxed and international travel has resumed, there will be approximately , competitors and in excess of , spectators building up to a potential , spectators in  ndash with an estimated economic impact of pound.m for the area.ldquoAt the present time, the event already has , entrants and a waiting list.Organisers of the race are reportedly targeting an annualacross the next five years, which could ldquopromote the Scottish Borders to a global audience.The council will offer organisers pound, ndash taken from the events budget ndash to help with the event,members approve recommendations at tomorrowrsquos meeting.:Man assaulted partner and then gave abuse to nurses at Borders General HospitalThe papers state: ldquoScottish Borders Council has been asked by the organisers of the EWS to provide a contribution of pound, to the overall project budget for the event.ldquoOfficers are working with the event organisers to develop the proposal and to clary the exact use of the funds along with the anticipated economic outcomes the event is seeking to achieve there is a strong fit with desired outcomes from major events and it is therefore recommended that pound, is allocated to this event subject to the normal application and review process.According to the council, it has previously been estimated that events generate and contribute over pound million per annum to the local economy.Alongside the money proposed to help the EWS, members will also be asked to approve the level of support given to events in  .Officers are recommending that up to pound, be offered to support an entirely new event in  or , while up to pound, could be given in  ldquoto prepare to hold an existing event in  where no event is being held in .Finally, pound, of support will be given to hold an existing event in members approve the plans.The EWS previously came to the Borders in .

title: empty-homes-officer-borders-council-approves-funding
story: THE Borders could get an empty homes officer in an attempt to bring vacant properties in the region back into use.Members of Scottish Borders Council will discuss the role, which  local authorities in Scotland now have, at the executive committee meeting on Tuesday .Councillors on the committee will be asked to approve the use of pound, to fund the full-time role for  months.Scottish Empty Homes Partnership, funded by the Scottish Government, will also contribute pound, towards the position for the two years.:Man assaulted partner and then gave abuse to nurses at Borders General HospitalA council paper, set to be discussed on Tuesday, states: ldquoThe costs of empty homes to the local economy impact on both the community and the council.ldquoCommunity impacts include reduction in property values, anti-social behaviour, vandalism, increased levels of stress and anxiety and a loss of community pride.ldquoBringing these properties back into use will help to reverse these negative effects.According to the paper, there are , lsquolong term empty propertiesrsquo in the Borders ndash . per cent of the total homes in the region .:Utter abomination: Suggested road changes in Borders town prove controversialldquoHomes lying empty cost communities in financial termsfor example in lost rent, lost local spending, cost of boarding up properties, dealing with and responding to anti-social behaviour, crime, and emergency services call-outs, the paper adds.ldquoBy proactively tackling empty homes in addition to saving on these costs, the estimated community spend generated through the re-occupation of an empty home is estimated as pound, per property per year.The overall vision for Scotland is that ldquono home remains empty.If approved, the empty homes officer will be available to provide assistance for homeowners, with the paper stating that it can cost between pound, and pound, to bring a property back into use.

title: coronavirus-galashiels-tests-people-no-symptoms
story: GALASHIELS will be offering tests later this week to people without coronavirus symptoms ndash giving locals a third opportunity.Testing was previously carried out in the town in late March and mid April at the volunteer hall.NHS Borders has now confirmed that coronavirustests will be offered between April - ndash but will take place in Queens Leisure Centre on Melrose Road.:Borders considers hiring empty homes officer to bring end to vacant propertiesNHS Bordersrsquo director of public health, Dr Tim Patterson, said: ldquoWe would like to thank the people of the Borders for good levels of engagement with our community testing programme as well as their input through exit surveys at testing facilities.ldquoInsights into why and when people come to be tested, amongst other helpful information, have led us to trial a new schedule which will provide more regular testing across the Borders.ldquoRegular COVID- testing is important especially as lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease and we will inevitably start mixing with other people more.ldquoNot everyone who has COVID- will have symptoms, so people could be spreading the disease without knowing it. We can only find these cases through testing and therefore stop the spread within our communities.:Outcry over bizarre plans to demolish historic mansion near the BordersAlso among the places offering testing this month are Kelsoand Jedburgh , with Selkirk carrying out tests on May  and .Tests will be available between .am and pm at each locationrsquos fire station.ldquoWe would encourage everyone who does not already receive regular testing through another route, such as their workplace or school, to consider getting a rapid COVID- test through our community testing programme, added Dr Patterson.ldquoIt takes about five minutes to get tested using a lateral flow deviceand your results will be sent to you by text message.

title: covid-rules-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-confirms-lockdown-easing
story: Nicola Sturgeon has today announced a final decision onthe proposed changes to the Covid rules due to take effect from Monday, April .These changes include the full reopening of retail services and partial reopening of the hospitality sector.The First Minister confirmed that all areas in mainland Scotland will move to level  meaning that bars, restaurants, retail shops and beauty salons can reopen from Monday.Here, we outline the key points from her briefing and the rules in level .. The lockdown exit planSpeaking of Scotlands lockdown exit strategy, Nicola Sturgeon said: "Taking all of the recent data into account, I am pleased to be able to confirm today that from Monday, April , those parts of the country that are currently in level  will move to level ."That of course includes all of mainland Scotland."We then expect that all of Scotland will move to level  on Monday, May ."That means, for example, that from May , people will be able to meet in small numbers in each otherrsquos homes, hospitality will reopen more fully, and outdoor contact sport for adults will resume."Then,circumstances permit, I can confirm that we will move to level  on Monday, June , before moving I hope to level  in late June ndash and then to something much more like normality over the course of the summer.". What is currently expected from April  Up to four people from two households can socialise indoors in a public place, such as a cafe or restaurant.Hospitality venues like cafes, pubs and restaurants can open until pm indoors ndash but without alcohol ndash and pm outdoors where alcohol is allowed to be consumed.Gyms can open for inidual exercise.All shops, stores and close contact services can open.Tourist accommodation can open with restrictions in place.Driving lessons and tests can resume.Funerals and weddings including post-funeral events and receptions can take place with up to  people, but no alcohol may be served.Indoor attractions and public buildings such as galleries, museums and libraries can open.Travel will also be allowed on this date to other parts of Britain, with reviews planned on journeys to Northern Ireland and the Republic.. ShieldingPeople on the shielding list canto work from MondayFrom next Monday, the Chief Medical Officerrsquos advice will be that people on the shielding list canto the workplace ndashyou cannot work from home.Like everyone ,you can work from home for now, you should.The First Minister said: "The last few months have been dficult for everyone ndash but have been especially dficult for people who are shielding."I am very grateful to you for everything you have done to keep yourselves and others safe. I very much hope that you enjoy being able to get out and about a little bit more, and that the understandable anxiety you have been living with is beginning to reduce.". TravelNicola Sturgeon confirmed that all remaining travel restrictions will be lted on April  for travel anywhere in Scotland, and for travel between Scotland, England and Wales.The Scottish Government will removerestrictions on travel to and from Northern Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man ndash though people should check the rules on entry to each of those territories before they travel.Due to low Covid rates in the Scottish Islands you are askedto take two lateral flow tests before you depart.The First Minister said: "If youre planning to travel to an island, we will encourage you to take two lateral flow tests before you depart."The second test should be on the day that you travel, and the first should be three days earlier."That means thatyou test positive, you have a chance to take a PCR test to confirm the result before you make a final decision on cancelling your visit.". Lateral FlowLateral flow testswill be available to anyone from April  ndash you can order online and find info on the Scottish Governmentwebsite or collect from covid testing centres in afternoon or evening.They can be ordered online for delivery to your home ndash you can find information on how to do that on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website.Alternatively, you can collect the tests from Covid testing centres in the afternoon or early evening.. The latest casesScotland has recorded two deaths from coronavirus and  positive tests in the past  hours, Ms Sturgeon said.It brings the death toll under this measure ndash of people who first tested positive for the virus within the previous  days ndash to ,.Giving a Covid- update, the First Minister said , people have now tested positive in Scotland, up from , the previous day.The daily test positivity rate is . per cent, down from . per cent.There are  people in hospital confirmed to have the virus, up two in  hours, and  patients are in intensive care, down one.Ms Sturgeon said ,, people have received their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine, up , from yesterday, and , have received their second dose.Heres what you can and cannot do in Level Can I get a pint Yes, in outdoor areas, such as beer gardens, alcohol is permitted with six people from six households.AmI allowed to goto the shops Yes, all non-essential shops will be open for business so you will be able to head to your favourite retailers.Can I travel around Scotland Yes, from April  you will be able to travel anywhere across Scotland.However, as lockdown levels change, people in level must not enter levels - or level  area unless for a permitted reason.Can I go on holiday Staycations will be permitted with travel restrictions lted and tourist accommodation will reopen.However, socialising rules must still apply.International travel will remain not permitted.Will bars, restaurants andcafes be open For indoors, pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes are also set to reopen on April  ndash however, this is only for meals and non-alcoholic drinks.They will be given a strict pm curfew and onlysix people from two households are allowed.Takeaway service will also continue to be open.Am I able to go to the gym Yes, gyms and indoor sports facilities including swimming pools and leisure centres will be open for inidual exercise.Group activity will be permitted for under s.Can I play contact sports No, contacts sports are not permitted until level .Will cinemas be open No, cinemas, theatres, concert halls, music venues, comedy clubs, amusement arcades, bingo halls and other entertainment centres cannot reopen until Level l.Can Isee my friends and family Yes, groups of six people from up to twohouseholds may socialise indoors in a public place. This does not includein-house socialising.However, one substantial change is thata maximum of sixpeople from up to sixhouseholds can meet outdoors.It is worth noting that under s do not count towards restricted numbers or households outdoors.Can I go into stadiums and attend events These will beclosedwith the exception of drive-in events.Can I take public transport You should continue to active travelwhere possible and avoid car sharing with people outside of your extended household.Face coverings will still be compulsory on public transport and, due to limited capacity,you are using public transport then plan ahead.What about childcare Nurseries, childminders and regulated school-age childcare providers are open.Informal childcare such as family and friendsare permitted.Can my child take part in after school activities Yes, but it will be subject to guidance.Can zoos and tourist attractions reopen Yes, all visitors centres can reopen for business.Should I still work from home You are encouraged to work from home where possible.Can I visit people in the hospital Yes, but the recommended family support from at least onevisitor per patient.Am I able to visit my loved ones in care homes Yes, however, the recommended minimum of twovisits per week, one person at a time. It should be essential visits only at all times.Will college and universities be open Yes, but it willbeblended learning.Can I get married Yes, and  people are allowed to attend the ceremony and thewedding reception.Alcohol is also permitted.Am I allowed to attend a funeral A maximum of  people are allowed to attend a funeral service and alcohol is permitted.Can I visit my place of worship Yes, places of worship will be open.Will libraries be open Yes, all public buildings are allowed toreopen on April .Are driving lessons allowed Yes, driving lessons will be restarted.Can I get work done indoors Work, such as home decorating, repairs etc areallowed indoors.Am I allowed to move home Yes, you are allowed to move home.

title: gala-academy-consultation-criticised-greens-co-convenor
story: A LEADING Borders environmentalist has criticised plans to build the new Galashiels Academy in Scott Park.Scottish Borders Councilis running an informal consultation on the proposals until Monday .But Charles Strang, the co-convenor of the Scottish Green Partyrsquos Borders branch, has expressed disappointment with the councilrsquos approach.In a letter, Mr Strang writes: ldquoOn the face of it this is not a genuine consultation, but a hollow exercise seeking to justy an education authority taking the easy option of expanding onto a greenfield site just because they think they can.Yet he adds: ldquoThe people who care about public open space, and trust in local government, should still be seeking to make their voices heard.A website launched by SBC last month tries to describe the decision-making behind the councilrsquos preferred plan.Before settling on Scott Park, the council ruled out three other sites ndash the town centre, Netherdale and Langlee.Within Scott Park, the council has outlined five ldquoareas but favours Area  because it is viewed as ldquothe most deliverable in terms of educational ality, community value, construction and cost.Although the school would be built in Scott Park, the council says the park would be ldquoextended, enhanced and reimagined as a result.The consultation website says: ldquoWhen the project is complete, the publicly accessible areas of Scott Park will have increased by more than . times to . hectares.However, as previously reported, the plan has been criticised by campaign group Save Scott Park.A petition, which now has more than , signatures, calls for the council to develop an ldquoalternative option.But the latest contribution to the debate comes from Mr Strang, , of the Borders Greens.Describing the consultation website, Mr Strang said: ldquoI donrsquot think it gives a fair or particularly clear portrayal of the process thus far.Mr Strang, a retired architect-planner, told the Border : ldquoI would start from a basic principle that building on Scott Park should be the last option that you would consider.The St Boswells resident feels the council is being ldquodisingenuous about the impact its preferred option would have on Scott Park.He said: ldquoEssentially this lsquoinformal consultationrsquo is a presentation of the selected option with no links to any options appraisal which may have been carried out on the four Gala sites, and only the most superficial assessment of the five options which are centred on the current site.ldquoIn particular I would have expected some explanation of the history of Scott Park and the reasons why the council feels there are no legal impediments to its use in this way.ldquoIt is disingenuous to argue that the areas around the new school would constitute a park. Some indication of Scott Parkrsquos status within the current and proposed Development Plans would also have aided transparency.ldquoNowhere do I see any attempt to reuse any of the existing buildings, which you might think might be a compelling reason in sustainability terms to examine this site rather more closely in the initial site search.ldquoAnd without a detailed brief being indicated, not only is it dficult to look at the fit and design options of the ious sites, but also it is unclear as to the centralisation of community facilities proposed here.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe council has made use of an online digital exercise supplemented with an unmanned exhibition in the Galashiels Transport Interchange to provide a robust consultation.ldquoWe would like to place on record our thanks to all of the people that have taken the time to submit comments on the proposals since the consultation went live on March .Anyone interested in making a comment can do so through the link on the councilrsquos website or directly to Galacampus@scotborders.gov.ukldquoFollowing the closure of this initial phase of the consultation, the feedback will be reflected upon and used to help prepare a report to the council in late spring recommending the next steps for the project.The full letter from Charles StrangI write on behalf of Scottish Borders Greens to draw your readersrsquo attention to the imminent closing date for submissions on the proposals for the ldquonew Gala Academy.Comments are due in on or before Monday  April. It has been suggested where, and in the columns of local newspapers, that this consultation is a sham.Why is it important that readers take the time and make the effort to respond to this consultation  It is not because the consultation itself has great merit.The Council itself has taken planning advice from consultants which tells them effectively that they need pay no attention to the results of any consultation.It may be that they have sought this independent advice because their own planners have maintained their professional judgements that the proposed site, given in perpetuity to the people of Galashiels as a ldquopleasure ground, is a key green space which should continue to be maintained as such.That is how they have described it in the recent consultative draft Local Development Plan, and no doubt in Development Plans before that.The Council appears reluctant to share their brief for this major improvement in secondary school provision for the Galashiels catchment area.It seems unlikely that, as has been suggested, there is no brief for this multi million pound expenditure: some form of brief would be essential to assess even one single option, never mind a range.Another useful role for any brief would be to examine the potential for retention of any of the educational facilities which already comprise the secondary school campus. This is a particularly important aspect when one considers the amount of embodied energy present in the existing buildings on the site. Plainly when one is addressing the sustainability of any development the existing buildings and site characteristics are critical factors.No, on the face of it this is not a genuine consultation, but a hollow exercise seeking to justy an Education Authority taking the easy option of expanding onto a greenfield site just because they think they can.The people who care about public open space, and trust in local government, should still be seeking to make their voices heard.

title: coronavirus-borders-sees-no-cases-recorded-last-24-hours
story: NO cases of coronavirus have been recorded in the Borders over the last  hours.The Scottish Government released the latest data at pm today .There have now been , cases of COVID-in the region since the start of the pandemic ndash an increase of one over the weekend.Nationally, , positive cases have been recorded since March last year.According to the most recent data, there are still fewer than five people in hospital in the Borders with the virus.This has been the case every day through March and April, .You might also be interested in:Borders could get pound.m boost from major eventset for region, says councilBorders considers hiring empty homes officerto bring end to vacant propertiesMan assaulted partner and then gave abuse to nursesat Borders General Hospital

title: scottish-parliament-election-borders-candidates-hustings
story: IN the lead-up to next monthrsquos Scottish Parliament elections, three hustings relevant to Borders voters will be held in the coming days.Tomorrowat .pm a virtual hustings over Zoom will be hosted by Borders environmental group Tweedgreen and Tweeddale Peace Group.This meeting will cover the constituency of Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale.All constituency candidates have been invited, with organisers saying questions will ldquofocus on the climate, peace and justice ndash all fundamental issues that are interlinked with the climate crisis, the COVID pandemic, and a green and just recovery from their effects.On Thursday eveningthe Liberal Democratsrsquo candidate for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, Catriona Bhatia, will participate in a National Farmers Unionhustings at pm .A spokesperson for the NFU said: ldquoThis webinar will give members the opportunity to hear from and question the lead rural affairs candidates from each of the five main parties.And on April  there will be a West Linton event held over Zoom between .pm-pm.The third Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale hustings will welcome candidates from the five main parties represented at this yearrsquos election ndash more candidates could be added before the event.To join tomorrows Tweedgreen event and submit questions, email: tweedgreenpeebles@googlemail visit the NFU Scotland Facebook page to access the Zoom link for Thursdayrsquos hustings and to join the West Linton meeting, register at: tinyurl wlhustings and send questions to westlintonhustings@gmail

title: broughton-john-buchan-way-trees-plan-opposed-campaigners
story: PROPOSALS to plant trees in a National Scenic Areain the Borders have been met with opposition from locals.The plans for Peeblesshires John Buchan Way involve afforestation across  hectares, mainly for commercial purposes to produce timber, while native broadleaves will also be planted.The new woodland creation would be set ldquowithin the property at Broughton Hope and would see trees planted in one of the Borders two National Scenic Areas.With the consultation process having started, Broughton Community Council was contacted by RDS Forestry, leading to opposition from the community.Fiona Pagett, who has lived in Broughton for  years, has set up a Facebook group called lsquoSave our Glen - JBWrsquo which now has more than  members.:Outcry over bizarre plans to demolish historic mansion near the BordersldquoIrsquom incredibly heartened, though not remotely surprised, at the immediate and enormous opposition to the planting proposal at Broughton Hope, said Ms Pagett, an estate agent.ldquoWe are becoming engulfed in Sitka spruce plantations as the Scottish Government ploughs towards its spurious target of mass planting in the belief this will solve climate change.ldquoIt is disregarding our treasured and erse landscape and threatening much flora and fauna, added Ms Pagett, who lives in the village with her son Angus and daughter Katie.ldquoI have high hopes that this particular proposal, which affects the John Buchan Way, local residents, the shepherd and would negatively impact tourism, will gain the attention of those able to stop it in its tracks.According to Ms Pagett, -year-old shepherd Geordie Wilsonrsquos role ldquowill be removedthe proposals on the land go ahead. Mr Wilson has spent the last seven years working on the area in his retirement, Ms Pagett said.:Utter abomination: Suggested road changes in Borders town prove controversialMeanwhile, concerns have been raised by locals regarding the impact on walkers, private water supplies and the ldquopanoramic views of the valley. The proposals would also involve the creation of a road to allow logging lorries access to the site.The community council has received a number of comments from concerned residents.One comment reads: ldquoThe worst part of the proposal for me is the approximately km section where the John Buchan Way will become forest road flanked directly on either side by serried ranks of coners.Another comment states: ldquoI have strong family connections to the glen as my ancestors were owners and farmers of it. I know for a fact that they would be turning in their graves at the very thought of this.:Award-winning filmmakers visited the Borders as part of their latest projectA spokesperson from RDS Forestry said: ldquoAs part of any potential new woodland creation proposal, due diligence is to be carried out in the form of site surveys and stakeholder consultation.ldquoIndependent surveys have been performed by qualied experts to identy potential constraints. These include an ornithology assessment, an archaeology ground survey and Phase  Habitat Assessment.ldquoOn completion of these surveys, we then engaged with stakeholders and the local community to determine other factors that need to be considered in the design process.ldquoOver the last few days we have received a number of consultation responses from both statutory stakeholders and members of the public. We are currently reviewing these and considering the comments received. This is the purpose of the stakeholder consultation, and is an important part of any new woodland creation project.The other National Scenic Area in the Borders is Eildon and Leaderfoot.

title: primark-glasgow-opening-times-revealed-lockdown-eases-monday
story: PRIMARK are preparing to reopen their doors as Scotland is set to move from Level  to Level  of the coronavirus lockdown on Monday.The bargain giant has revealed its new opening times as staff are restocking their shelves and getting set to welcome customers back for the first time this year.Although shoppers wont be treated to a-hour reopening seen last year, some stores are reopening their doors at am while others will operate for  hours.A Primark spokeswoman said: "We are really looking forward to welcoming our customers back to our stores in Scotland."We know our customers will love our amazing new Spring Summer ranges, including bright leisurewear in spring pastels, as well as some exciting new collaborations with Disney and Pineapple, which will all be in-store when we re-open."As always, safety remains our top priority and we will continue to have extensive safety measures in place to help ensure that our employees and customers cantoPrimarkwith confidence.Bosses have confirmed the following opening times for Scottish stores:Argyle Street, Glasgow - am - pmSauchiehall Street, Glasgow - am - pmBraehead, Renfrewshire,- am - pmUnion Street, Aberdeen - .am-.pmTaran Walk, Ayr - .am - pmRivergate Centre, Irvine - am - pmHigh Street, Dundee - am - pmFort Kinnaird, Edinburgh- am - pmHigh Street, Dunfermline - am - pmHamilton Way, Greenock - am - pmBridge Street, Inverness - .am - pmQuarry Street, Hamilton - .am - pmBrandon Place South, Motherwell - .am - pmAlmondvale South, Livingston- am - pmOther reopening times can be checked HERE.

title: lateral-flow-tests-scotland-book-free-home-covid-test
story: Free Covidtesting packages will beavailable for home delivery in Scotland from next week - eventhey do not have symptoms.Nicola Sturgeon announcedthat Scotswill be able to order lateral flow tests for home delivery from Monday  April.The quick test packages are part of a universal testing initiative to be introduced across the country, following their introduction in England and for senior school pupils.Speaking at the Covid briefing, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed plans for Scots to haveaccess to the fastertests, which can give results within just  minutes.People can order test packages online for home delivery by following details on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website.Alternatively, the nose and throat swab tests can be collected from covid testing centres in the afternoons or early evening.How to order a lateral flow testYou can order free packs of rapid lateral flow tests to be sent to your homeyou live in Scotland, are over  and:have been asked to test by your local authority or NHS PublicHealthteamhave someone on the shielding list in your householdare planning to travel to a Scottish islandcannot get tests from your work, school, college or universityYou should not use this serviceyou have:coronavirus symptoms ndashuse thetesting service for people who have symptomsinsteadbeen asked to self-isolateA rapid lateral flow testpack contains seventests.You can only order one pack per household each day.Where can I order tests You can order a test here.If you have someone on the shielding list in your household or are planning to travel to a Scottish island, select yes when the site asksyou were asked to get tested by a local authority or by an NHS Public Health team.For those travelling to a Scottish island, they should also click Scotland under the where in the UK do you live question, eventhey live in England, Wales or Northern Ireland.What did Nicola Sturgeon say Speaking at her dailybriefing, Ms Sturgeon said: "Two weeks ago I indicated that we would make lateral flow tests available to anyone in Scotland who wants one."I can confirm therefore that lateral flow testing will be available to anyone in Scotland from  April."You can order later flow test online for delivery to your home ndash and you can find information on how to do that on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website."Alternatively, you can collect the tests from Covid testing centres in the afternoon or early evening."I would encourage everyone to take advantage of this offer ndash but I want to highlight one issue in particular today where we are really encouraging people to make sure they use lateral flow testing as appropriate."Where testing takes place - community testing sitesIfyou do not have coronavirus symptoms but live in a community that has been targeted for testing, you can access a test at a rapid test site.These are only available in some parts of Scotland.You can usually just turn up and do not need to book in advance ndash but you should check the arrangements at your local site first.You will be tested using a lateral flow devicewhich involves taking a swab or saliva sample.You should usually get your result within an hour.Island testingThe First Minister also added that people visiting the islands should take two lateral flow tests before travelling.Nicola Sturgeon said: "We are keeping island communities at the same level as the rest of the country at the moment, so that we can allow travel between island communities and the rest of Scotland."But we know this does create a risk for our island communities."Many of them currently have very, very low rates of Covid."And they will be welcoming visitors from parts of Scotland which I know many of them are looking forward to where Covid will still be circulating at a higher level and more widely."So If you are planning to travel to an island we do encourage you to take two lateral flow tests before you depart."The second test should be on the day that you are planning to travel, and the first should be three days before you travel."That means thatyou test positive, you have a chance to take a PCR test - which is more sensitive - to confirm the result before making a final decision on cancelling your visit."This is potentially an important way in which we can minimise the risk, of bringing Covid into island communities while nevertheless allowing our island communities the benefit of opening up again to visitors."Soyou are planning on travelling to an island over the course of next week, it is possible to get tests from today, and I would encourage you to do that."

title: nicola-sturgeon-borders-telegraph-interviews-snp-leader
story: We invited all major political parties in Scotland to take part in an interview ahead of the Scottish Parliament elections on May . In this instalment ndash the last of the series ndash we speak to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, the leader of the SNP.Q. What is your party planning to do in the Borders A. Obviously for the Borders, as with the whole of the country, recovery from COVID is a top priority.To get the economy growing again, to support retail, to support tourism.Central to that, of course, will be infrastructure.The SNP has already delivered a signicant infrastructure project, which is very important to the Borders, in terms of the railway.Our manesto will set out plans to build on that and to go further. But to get the economy of the Borders up and running again, and to support growth and the overall wellbeing of people living in the Borders, will be a top priority.Q. Like many local authorities, Scottish Borders Council has declared a climate emergency. What is your party doing on that front A. I think the Scottish Government led the way in declaring a climate emergency.The Scottish Parliament in the last term of parliament has passed what, by any standards, are considered to be world-leading targets to become a net zero emissions country by . And to achieve by  a  per cent reduction in emissions.That puts us right at the leading edge of ambition in terms of ending our contribution to climate change. Setting the targets is the easy bit.Delivering that is, obviously, much more challenging. At the end of last year we published an updated climate change plan including about  dferent policies across how we heat our homes, how we travel around, agriculture, reducing emissions in industry, that will be necessary to meet those targets.Government has a leadership role to play, but to succeed we have to work in partnership with local authorities and, indeed, with the private sector.Obviously, hosting the COP  in Glasgow later this year will be a real catalyst, I think, for the Scottish Government and everybody in Scotland to showcase our ambition, but also to showcase what we are doing and encourage the rest of the world to join with us.Q. You have said that you would like an independent Scotland to join the EU. Would that mean a potentially damaging hard border between Scotland and the rest of the UK A. I donrsquot want a border. I have never wanted a border. I donrsquot want a hard border in future.In terms of the free movement of people, an independent Scotland would continue to be in the common travel area.So there would be no hard border in terms of people.Obviously, in terms of goods and services, our priority would be to keep trade flowing.It is Brexit that has created the issues of borders and many of our exports right now are facing real dficulty and losing a lot of business and a lot of money because of the border dficulties from the UK to the rest of Europe.Independence gives us the opportunity to become part of the European single market again ndash seven times the size of the UK market ndash but to continue to work with the UK and EU to keep trade flowing in both directions between Scotland and England.Q. What would you say your biggest goal was in an independent Scotland A. My biggest goal right now and in an independent Scotland is to make Scotland the best place in the world to grow up.Make it a great country for children to learn in, to grow up in, to make sure we can eradicate child poverty and for Scotland to be a confident, prosperous, fair and equal country.We know that is possible becausewe look across Europe right now at countries very similar in size to Scotland, but often without the vast natural resources that Scotland has, these are countries that are amongst the wealthiest, the fairest and the happiest countries in the world.If places like Norway and Denmark can do that, there is absolutely no reason why Scotland canrsquot as well.Q. Why do you think Scotland voted lsquonorsquo in  A. There is no doubt a iety of reasons.Scotland came closer to voting lsquoyesrsquo than many people would ever have predicted.For people like me, we have to continue to build support, trust and confidence and persuade people. In ,  per cent of people voted lsquoyesrsquo. Most opinion polls right now, including one just published in the last hour [the Border spoke to Ms Sturgeon on April ], show that independence is now supported by a majority of people in Scotland. So already we have moved on signicantly from .Once the COVID pandemic is over, I think people in Scotland should have the right to consider that again and make their choice.Readersrsquo questionsQ. Scotlandrsquos PISAresults in science and maths have dropped under SNP governments. Why has education got worse under the SNP A. We look at the data for exam results in Scotland, we see both attainment rising and the attainment gap closing.We have still got more work to do.That is why we are investing heavily in education and in education recovery, in more teachers.We have invested, over the last parliament, three quarters of a billion pounds specically closing the attainment gap.When we publish our manesto next week, we will set out our plans for the next parliament. Scottish education is high quality.There is work to do to make sure it continues to improve and that we close the poverty-related attainment gap. Part, of course, closing the poverty-related attainment gap is not just focusing on attainment in schools, but focusing on poverty.And we have already taken more action than any previous government in Scotland ndash establishing the Scottish Child Payment, for example, and wersquove put forward plans in this election to double that in the next parliament.A key part in raising educational attainment is to lt children out of poverty.Q. Would there be an Indyref ,you were to lose a second independence referendum A. I donrsquot intend for that to be the situation, so it is a completely hypothetical question.

title: queen-issues-statement-time-great-sadness-birthday
story: The Queen has sent a message to people across the world to mark her th birthday.In a statement released by the Royal Family on behalf of the Queen, Her Majesty thanked people across the UK, the Commonwealth and around the world for their kindness and support during a time of ldquogreat sadness.The statement read: ldquoI have, on the occasion of my th birthday today, received many messages of good wishes, which I very much appreciate.ldquoWhile as a family we are in a period of great sadness, it has been a comfort to us all to see and hear the tributes paid to my husband, from those withing the United Kingdom, the Commonwealth and around the world.ldquoMy family and I would like to thank you for all the support and kindness shown to us in recent days.ldquoWe have been deeply touched, and continue to be reminded that Philip had such an extraordinary impact on countless people throughout his le.The Queenrsquos message to people across the world who have sent tributes and messages of condolence following the death of The Duke of Edinburgh. pic apWszXSmdash The Royal FamilyApril , Members of the monarchy have been supporting the Queen throughout the mourning period for Philip, and some of her family are expected to be with her at Windsor Castle.It is the first birthday she has celebrated without her husband for more than  years.Boris Johnson said he is ldquoproud to serve as the Queenrsquos Prime Minister as the monarch marks her th birthday privately following the death of her ldquobeloved husband the Duke of Edinburgh.The Prime Minister wrote on Twitter: ldquoI would like to send my warm wishes to Her Majesty The Queen on her th birthday.ldquoI have always had the highest admiration for Her Majesty and her service to this country and the Commonwealth.ldquoI am proud to serve as her Prime Minister.Philiprsquos family and friends gathered at St Georgersquos Chapel in Windsor on Saturday to say their final farewell to the duke, who died peacefully on April .His death came a few months before his th birthday, which was due to be the focus of royal celebrations this year, while the Queenrsquos th was to be more low-key.After  years of married le the Queen now reigns alone without the support of her ldquostrength and stay, as she famously described her late husband.

title: enduro-world-series-scottish-borders-council-give-funds
story: ORGANISERS of a major event ing to the Borders this year will receive up to pound, of council support.During a meeting yesterday , Scottish Borders Councils executive committee agreed to help mountain bikings Enduro World Series .Rob Dickson, the councilrsquos executive director, said the money was ldquoconsistent with funding given to other events.:Borders could get pound.m boost from major event set for region, says councilldquoThe consequences of COVID-have been far-reaching and responding to that has been challenging, Mr Dickson told members.ldquoWe think itrsquos right and proper to provide dedicated funding for planning an event.Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatler, an independent member, said: ldquoThe Enduro World Series would be a fantastic start to building back our events programme.ldquoItrsquos important that we get behind that this year and the coming years.:Outraged Borders residents slam plans for new trees on treasured landThe EWS is scheduled to come to the Tweed Valley in the autumn.It was previously hosted in the region in .Organisers are said to be keen for the event tofor a further four years after the forthcoming edition.

title: empty-homes-officer-new-role-borders-40k-approved
story: A NEW council role will be created in the Borders to help solve the costly problem of vacant properties in the region.Members of Scottish Borders Councilrsquosexecutive committee approved the use of pound, to fund an empty homes officer on Tuesday .According to SBC papers, there are more than , lsquolong termrsquo empty properties across the Borders, with council leader Shona Haslam describing the introduction of the new role as ldquoincredibly important.There are  local authorities in Scotland that have an empty homes officer, the papers state.Mark Rowley, Conservative representative for Mid Berwickshire, said: ldquoI was embarrassed we were one of the councils which didnrsquot have this position.ldquoThat absolutely has to change.:Borders considers hiring empty homes officer to bring end to vacant propertiesMr Rowley added that addressing the problem of empty homes will be a ldquokey part of town centre regeneration.The funding will allow an empty homes officer to operate in the Borders for two years, with the Scottish Empty Homes Partnership also contributing pound, towards the position.After  months a review of the position will be carried out, according to SBCrsquos housing strategy officer Donna Bogdanovic.Galashiels councillor Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said: ldquoIf you go up Hall Street then yoursquore going up Kirkbrae and you look up to the right therersquos all these deserted flats.In response to Mr Jardinersquos query about whether these properties would be looked at, Ms Bogdanovic said: ldquoWersquove done a lot of work with Kirkbrae.She added that there are sometimes ldquocomplex issues why homes are empty, with the possibility of looking at loans ldquoto give people a nudge to address their properties.

title: prince-philips-complaint-queen-revealed
story: Despite more than  years of marriage, Prince Philip only ever had one complaint about the Queen, according to a royal expert.Biographer Gyles Brandreth appeared on Lorraine on ITV to remember the Duke of Edinburgh as the Queen celebrated her th birthday.The Queen lost her husband on Friday, April  at the age of . He was buried last weekend at St Georgersquos Chapel.Lorraine asked her guest for his memories of the Duke which he was happy to share with viewers.He said: "Well, the only time he ever complained about the Queen. He knew his whole le was the Queen."He would always turn up, dressed, one step behind her. He served her. But he did tell me once - he did say to me oh, she is never off the phone."Gyles added: "Never off the phone. Who is she talking to  Well, I tell you, I think she was probably - and this, in a sense, is the hope for the future - is that I think she was on the phone in the evening to her horse racing managers about the horses."I think in the afternoon she would take her dogs for a walk every day."Gyles described the time he was told off by Prince Philip, a stickler for detail, about a fact he got wrong about the Dukersquos father in a book."My father did not float down to the south of France. My father went by train,"Gyles recalled."He wanted things to be accurate."On Wednesday the Queen sent a message of thanks to the nation during a time of ldquogreat sadness.In a Buckingham Palace statement, released on behalf of the Queen, tributes were paid to the late Prince Philip.It read: ldquoI have, on the occasion of my th birthday today, received many messages of good wishes, which I very much appreciate.ldquoWhile as a family we are in a period of great sadness, it has been a comfort to us all to see and hear the tributes paid to my husband, from those withing the United Kingdom, the Commonwealth and around the world.ldquoMy family and I would like to thank you for all the support and kindness shown to us in recent days.ldquoWe have been deeply touched, and continue to be reminded that Philip had such an extraordinary impact on countless people throughout his le.

title: grandmother-91-pfizer-jab-first-urges-people-get-second-covid-dose
story: A -year-old grandmother who became the first person in the world to have the Pfizer vaccine as part of the mass vaccination rollout has praised ldquoincredible NHS staff and urged people to get their second dose.The face of Margaret Keenan ndash known as Maggie ndash made news around the world in December last year after she was given the coronavirus jab at University Hospital Coventry.In a Zoom call with NHS chief executive Sir Simon Stevens, the grandmother of four was asked what she would say to anyone feeling hesitant about getting a second jab.Mrs Keenan replied: ldquoI would be saying lsquogo and get it, and get it nowrsquo.ldquoBecause itthe best thing theyrsquove ever done, really.the best thing I ever did.vw,vw,px, px"Margaret Keenan, with matron May Parsons ldquoI hope everybody comes forward.ldquoSome people are just afraid of injections but therersquos nothing to it.ldquoYou donrsquot feel anything.Asked about how she felt being the first to have the jab, she added: ldquoI feel really honoured to have it done and to be the first and set the ball rolling.Mrs Keenan said that, having since had her second dose, she was now most looking forward to ldquoa little holiday, adding with a laugh ldquoIrsquom not greedy!The nonagenarian, who only retired from her job working in a jewellerrsquos four years ago, also praised NHS doctors and nurses for their work during the rollout.She said: ldquoTheyrsquore incredible, I cannot find words to say hellip they are really incredible for what theyrsquove done.ldquoI think the NHS has achieved an enormous lot by doing the work they do.vw,vw,px, px"Sir Simon Stevens praised Margaret Keenan ldquoIt is such a wonderful institution.Mrs Keenan, who has lived in Coventry for more than  years but is originally from Enniskillen, Northern Ireland, received the Zoom earlier this week, where she was reunited with matron May Parsons.It was Ms Parsons, matron for respiratory medicine at University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust, who administered Mrs Keenanrsquoshistoric first jab on December  .Ms Parsons, who has worked for the NHS for almost  years since moving from the Philippines, said: ldquoThe dawn is coming, wersquore going to be coming out of this.ldquoI cannot be more excited and I canrsquot be more positive about.ldquoWersquore coming out of this pandemic, stronger.She added a ldquomassive thank you to her NHS colleagues, for their ldquocompassion, ldquobravery and courage throughout the last year.vw,vw,px, px"Mrs Keenan was the first person in the world to have the Pfizer vaccine as part of the mass vaccination rollout Thanking the pair on the call, Sir Simon said: ldquoMaggie, yoursquove been an inspiration.ldquoMay, yoursquove set the whole of the health service on the path towards this hugely successful vaccine rollout.Separately, the NHS boss said: ldquoWersquore seeing patients coming forward in record numbers for their Oxford AstraZeneca second doses.ldquoPeople are voting with their feet, showing continuing strong public support for the NHS Covid vaccination campaign which has already saved over , lives.The NHS vaccine programme, the biggest in health service history and the most rapid rollout in Europe, is continuing to ramp up second doses for the most vulnerable.The programme has now protected about  million people in England with at least one jab, also delivering more than nine million second doses." data-title"HEALTH Coronavirus" data--holder"PA Graphics" data--notice"PA Graphics Press Association Images" data-credit"PA Graphics" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eaebbaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjEMTcMzU ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eaebbaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjEMTcMzU ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eaebbaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjEMTcMzU ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Although the NHS focus is on second doses, appointments are still available for those in the initial priority groups who have not yet been protected.People who had their first jab at a vaccination centre or pharmacy-led service should already have a date for their second while those jabbed by a GP will be called back.Anyone aged  and over can still arrange their jab, as well as people who are clinically vulnerable or a health and care worker, who should contact their GP for an appointment.The NHS is also inviting those eligible for a jab by letter and text, with some GPs also calling unvaccinated patients personally to encourage uptake.Doctors, nurses and other health care workers are administering injections at more than , sites, from cathedrals, mosques and temples to racecourses, stadiums, cinemas title: mike-ashley-ordered-reinstate-jenners-signs-edinburgh-landmark
story: Mike Ashley has been ordered to reinstate the letters of the Jenners sign after they were removed from the Edinburgh landmark.City of Edinburgh Council has issued a formal notice to Sports Direct International, now Frasers Group PLC, over work ldquoexecuted to the listed buildinghellip having regard to the effect of the works on the character of the building as one of special architectural or historic interest.Jenners has been a landmark department store on Princes Street for more than  years, previously trading as an independent shop until it was acquired by House of Fraser in .Mr Ashleyrsquos company is alleged by the council to have ldquowithout listed building consent removed ldquothe inidual letters forming lsquoJennersrsquo located at high level on both the easternand southernelevations.vw,vw,px, px"Mike Ashleyrsquos Frasers Group has been issued an enforcement notice over the matter The council says the firm is required to ldquoreinstate the letters to their original location on the eastern and southern elevations of the department store to form the name lsquoJennersrsquo.Another section of the noticeconfirms the letters are intact and are ldquocurrently stored in the department store.The company has been given three months to comply after the notice takes effect on Friday May .Mr Ashley can appeal against the notice, but the council said ldquoany appeal must be received, or posted in time to be received, by Scottish ministers before that date.Earlier this year it was announced the store was to close with the loss of  jobs after Frasers Group failed to reach an agreement with owner Anders Polvsen to continue the lease on the building.The company has been contacted for comment..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Mike Ashley ordered to reinstate Jenners signs on Edinburgh landmark

title: brexit-disruption-ni-medicine-supply-lines-unacceptable---minister
story: Stormontrsquos Health Minister has voiced concern about the supply line of medicines to Northern Ireland as a result of a looming Brexit regulatory barrier.Under the terms of Brexitrsquos contentious Northern Ireland Protocol, the region is to operate under dferent regulatory rules for medicines and medical devices than the rest of the UK.Northern Ireland currently secures % of its supplies from Great Britain.A one-year grace period delaying the implementation of this aspect of the protocol is due to expire at the end of the year.vw,vw,px, px"Unionists and loyalists in Northern Ireland claim Brexit has created new barriers between the region and the rest of the UK Health Minister Robin Swann told his Assembly scrutiny committee that the EUrsquos ill-fated attempt to suspend a part of the protocol in January, amid a dispute with vaccine manufacturers over exporting jabs out of the bloc, had impacted efforts to prepare for the end of the grace period.ldquoIt is something that concerns me and thatrsquos why we have been engaged quite signicantly in regards to this, he said.ldquoThe derogation period for medicines was one of the longest that was actually agreed at the start which gave us to the end of this year actually to get things sorted out and in a better place.ldquoEveryone thought that work was progressing well until the EU triggered Article  over vaccines ndash that unnerved people, that unsettled people and that has, I suppose, increased the level of concern that wersquore seeing, especially from the smaller and the more intricate suppliers of supply issue lay with ongoing negotiations between the UK and EU on resolutions to some of the problems created by the protocol.ldquoIt would be unacceptable that our medicines or medical devices are impacted and the supply of them, he said.ldquoWe are a small part of the overall UK market in regards to many of these big pharma companies and I see no reason why we should be treated dferently.vw,vw,px, px"The protocol requires new inspection posts at NI ports for goods arriving from the rest of the UK Mr Swann told the Stormont health committee he would welcome any further extension.ldquoWhen grace periods were initially indicated the one for medicines and medical devices was the longest because they indicated and they knew the dficulties that were going to be what political movements or decisions or discussions or agreements can be made between the UK Government and the EU, specically in regards to the supply of medicines to Northern Ireland.Mr Swann was
