title: Buildings lit up blue to honour Duke of Edinburgh’s passing
story: LOCAL DUP councillors have welcomed the decision to illuminate two of the districtrsquos major buildings with blue lighting as a mark of respect to Prince Philip whose funeral service was held last Saturday.Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Down Leisure Centre in Downpatrick and Newry Town Hall were lit in blue on the eve of the funeral.Cllrs Glyn Hanna, Kathryn Owen and Billy Walker have praised local authority chairwoman, Laura Devlin, for agreeing to the move and also opening an on-line book of condolence.Cllr Hanna said Prince Philip gave the UK and the Commonwealth a ldquoletime of service, creating the Duke of Edinburgh awards which young people from all sides of our community have taken part in.ldquoThe Prince was also patron of many charities and had a massive interest in the environment and protecting our plant, Cllr Hanna continued.ldquoHe was also a veteran of World War Two and was commended for his bravery. Prince Philiprsquos generation is fast disappearing and I thank the council for lighting up these building in blue to mark the Duke of Edinburghrsquos passing.Cllrs Owen and Walker said they were also pleased that the local authority had marked the passing of the Duke of Edinburgh..prettyPhoto

title: Club setback
story: DOWNPATRICK Cricket Club will not be taking part in league cricket for the first time in living memory this year.With the new season just weeks away, the club says it is unable to compete in Section  of the NCU owing to a lack of players.However, the club will be competing in the Junior Cup and will aim to play friendlies and T competitions.The club is undergoing a period of transition as they seek to invest in the development of their youth players.Club president John Thompson said it was a challenging time for the club, but insisted that brighter days lay ahead.ldquoWe are going through a transitory period, but we have young players coming through and we are hopeful for the future, he remarked.In a statement issued on Facebook, the club said: ldquoDue to lack of player availability we will not be entering a team for the league format for the  season.ldquoWe will be entering the Junior Cup and we will continue to do all we can to protect the future of cricket in Downpatrick.The statement continued: ldquoInstead of the league fixtures we will be approaching other clubs who may have a free weekend to offer them a shorterfriendly match.ldquoWe must thank the NCU for their ongoing support during this time and we will continue to engage with them.ldquoWeather permitting, training will start next week. Anyone who wants to come down and join us will be made more than welcome.The club have a rich history, claiming six NCU league titles between  and . They have also won the Challenge Cup four times and the Irish Cup on two occasions.The club suffered relegation from the leaguersquos top flight and concerns over availability of players first surfaced in .Last year it was announced that the club was ping down to Section  and would only be fielding one team.In November club chairman Paul Linehan made a plea for players to come forward. ldquoWe have lost a number of key and experienced players over recent years, he said.ldquoThe reasons for that are complex. Certainly with relegation came a dilution in the quality of players we had available to us.ldquoAs well as that, there is natural loss, players get older, retire, people go off to university or jobs in England. When you add all of those things up, it is dficult to recover from the loss of so many players in a short period of time..prettyPhoto

title: De La Salle says welcome back
story: DE LA SALLE High School in Downpatrick recently welcomed all of its students back to the classrooms.The school opened its doors with great excitement and anticipation as pupils and teachers met for the first time in four months.Despite ongoing Covid- restrictions still in place, students were laughing and smiling at seeing their fellow classmates again whilst finally being able to speak to their teachers in a non-virtual environment.Year  student Conor said he was ldquodelighted to get back to school as he missed his friends and lsquothe teaching and non-teaching staffrsquo who had been so kind to him during lockdown.Mr Kevin Murray, Head of Pastoral Care, said: ldquoIt feels like a huge celebration of homecoming. Google Classroom, Microsoft Teams and Zoom can never take the place of face-to-face teaching or pastoral care.Each form tutor took their pupils through a re-induction booklet designed by Barnardorsquos, to help the pupils reconnect with school, rebuild their relationships and address any fears or anxieties they may have.Pupils were also reminded of the ious support networks in the school available to them, and how they can avail of the school mentoring systemthey need longer term support to readjust or to deal with any learning or pastoral issues due to lockdown.ldquoThe school will be working to its capacity to re-acclimatise the pupils to the classroom and to promote a positive atmosphere of reconnection, said Mr Murray.ldquoI am very proud of the efforts of our teaching and non-teaching staff during lockdown to reach out to pupils and their families, providing them with support and optimism..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick museum prepares to open Armstong hut replica
story: THE pandemic did not stopped work on a faithful recreation at Down Country Museum of a historic wartime base which was home to thousands of people.The construction of a  period Armstrong hut, formerly used at Ballykinlar Camp, has been taking place in the museumrsquos central courtyard to mark the original building and use of the huts as part of the Decade of Centenaries commemorations.More than  inidual stories of former hut occupants will bring the faithfully reconstructed hut to le, sharing how many people found themselves in this part of the district in some of the most troubled times in the last century.The work has been continuing since the museum was closed to the public since March last year, with it only briefly re-opening for two weeks in late September and early October.Despite the closure, staff have been working behind the scenes at the popular Downpatrick museum, either engaging in digital training activity o assisting the council in erse ways throughout the pandemic.The museum secured funding for an Access Audit which has facilitated several short films about the collections.Staff have also maintained a daily presence on Facebook, posting images of items from the collections, and telling the story of the museumrsquos history, as  marks the th anniversary of the founding of the museum.However, the museumrsquos key lockdown project is the recreation of the  period Armstrong hut.The project is a Newry, Mourne and Down Council Shared History Project, supported by the European Unionrsquos PEACE IV Programmeand managed by the Special EU Programmes Body .The hut will be fitted out internally to tell the stories of people who occupied the huts between  and , exploring their experiences of the lsquoWorldrsquos End Camprsquo - so-called because of its remote and windswept location, which stuck in the memories of all its inhabitants over the decades.Mike King, the museumrsquos assistant director, explained the unique history behind Ballykinlar Camp used throughout both world wars.ldquoThe camp is well-known for being the location where , Belfast men trained in - for action in the First World War, as part of the thDivision, that fought at the battle of the Somme. It was also a staging post for US troops of the st Armored Division and th Infantry Division between  and , as they prepared for major Second World War campaigns in North Africa and Europe.ldquoThe camp was also a place of imprisonment for over , republicans from all over Ireland during the Irish War of Independence from December  to December , and from  to , it was used to imprison German prisoners of war, captured in France after D-Day.ldquoLess well known are the evacuees who escaped the Siege of Malta in the Second World War, and the Hungarian refugees who escaped from the invading Russian army in -, destined for a new le in Canada.ldquoAll these people and many more, were housed in huts at Ballykinlar, many of which survived up until , when the last one was dismantled.Mr King said that during the process of the huts being removed, Andrew Carlisle and his team discovered hundreds of artefacts buried in the sand underneath the hut and donated them to the museum.Many artefacts have been donated for an introductory display, including a chess set used in the camp in  by Michael Phelan, the uncle of Martin Sheen, the Hollywood actor.During lockdown, William Rogers Contracts of Annalong was appointed, through the EU funded project, to construct an exact copy of a Ballykinlar Armstrong Hut, using the original plans from August  .Mr King added that the hut will be ready for visitors once the museum is able to safely welcome people across its doors once again.He said: ldquoThe hut structure has now been completed, with a genuine antique Portway stove being restored and ready to be moved into place.ldquoCurrently, work is proceeding to gather furniture and props for the hut interior and to create interpretation for visitors. The hut offers many opportunities for educational events and living history in the future.ldquoWith this work going on, regular maintenance of the buildings and care of collections, itrsquos hoped the museum will be able to re-open, and all staffto work, in line with the government timeline and safety advice, during the summer.Cllr Laura Devlin, chairwoman of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, said: lsquoItrsquos great news that the EU-funded Ballykinlar History Hut project has been able to continue during lockdown, and we appreciate the work of the contractors who made this possible throughout a dficult period for everyone.ldquoThe efforts to achieve authenticity have been commendable, and the completed hut promises to be a veritable time-machine, waiting to transport visitors back to a century ago when it opens.ldquoI know that over  stories of former hut occupants have been collected from families and relatives, and I wish all involved the best of luck in bringing the project to a successful conclusion. The council will keep everyone informed of the re-opening schedules for its buildings and services as the health situation develops.rsquoMatch funding for this project has been provided by the Executive Office in Northern Ireland and the Department for Rural and Community Development in Ireland..prettyPhoto

title: End of lockdown welcome
story: WHEN East Down Athletics Club met way back on Thursday, December , to take part in the annual Christmas predicted time trial, the athletes were all too aware that it was going to be the last club activity for a while as the NI Executive had just announced stringent restrictions in a reaction to rising numbers of Covid-.Even though the runners had to social distance and were split into groups of , the fun night had an air of the last hurrah.There were prizes awarded to those who had managed to run closest to the times that they had predicted in advance and Jonny Holmes claimed fth place in the rankings.Jonny had to leave early that night and so was not there when the results were announced. Little did he know that it would be  long weeks till he would be back at club training in order to pick up his reward.Luckily his prize of a Wrap  Roll voucher does not go out of date and he is looking forward to a lunchtime treat from their tempting menu.After a very long lockdown, sport for some finally got the green light last week and from Monday, April , East Down AC runners along with other affiliated clubs were allowed to meet in groups of .Athletics Northern Ireland, as our national governing body, has been drip-feeding Covid- updates throughout the pandemic and ensuring that members are up to date on what is permissible under the guidelines and how to safely carry out sessions when regulations allow group training.One of the required criteria is having a Covid- officer who is responsible for keeping the register of those attending as well as encouraging social distancing and other hygiene measures.Paul Burns, who had been in that role since last March, has gratefully handed over to Kevin Kelly for the year ahead. It is an important job but a necessary appointmentthe club is to operate safely. We are still unable to use the clubrooms, but at least we are free to train together.As well as Jonny Holmes, there were a few other lucky people in the club able to collect winnings. During lockdown there have been member draws at the end of each month for those who have participated in the ious challenges set by the coaches.Eamon Kelly and Kelly Smith saved themselves some money as they each won free membership for  .There was also a draw to encourage members to pay their dues in a timely manner. As the renewal date of April , , drew near, there was a surge of payments which made Donal Smithrsquos job as membership secretary a lot simpler. It meant he could have all the paperwork done in time for training to recommence.On the first night back, Nuala Taylorrsquos name was drawn out of the hat and she was delighted to win a voucher for Teamwear Ireland. She will have no excuse for not having the latest gear when racing resumes. Nor will Declan Hampton as he also won a Teamwear Ireland voucher in the February Junior draw. Congratulations to all who picked up a prize.Some runners admitted to feeling slightly nervous at the call toto training because they were concerned that they might not have done enough in the layoff to be able to keep up with the group but as usual no one was left hanging.Even though we are allowed to meet in s, most runs end up splitting into smaller groups anyway so that you run with someone your own speed and no man or woman is ever left behind. After the first sessions back were complete, all agreed that having a buddy to push you on is a great encourager.On that note, East Down AC is always open to new senior members andyou have been running solo as a way of keeping fit during lockdown, it is the perfect time to join us and experience the camaraderie that comes from running with others.Members of a club benefit from coached sessions and guidance on how to attain their goals whatever they may be. At East Down AC we have runners who do parkrun, road and trail Ks and Ks and those who train for marathon and ultra marathon distance events.We have members who prefer cross country or mountain running and those who like track racing We have some who turn up week on week simply to keep fit and to have a bit of craic.There is truly something for everyone. At pound for a full yearrsquos membership, it is great value as this also includes affiliation to ANI with reduced race entry costs and insurance cover. If you are interested then message the East Down AC Facebook page or email membership@eastdownac. You will be made most welcome and can lsquotry before you buyrsquo.We train at pm Monday and Thursday in and around Downpatrick but due to Covid- restrictions on numbers, it is necessary to contact us before turning up.With the first week of training under our belts, spirits are high and we are looking forward to making the most of the bright nights and the better weather.From a racing perspective, things are also moving in the right direction with an announcement that from this Friday, competitive outdoor sport can be organised by a club, inidual or iniduals affiliated, with numbersnot exceeding  and no spectators permitted.This is great news. We are not out of the woods as far as the pandemic is concerned but keeping active is key and the chance for some social interaction mdash albeit from a distance mdash as we do so, is great news for all concerned..prettyPhoto

title: Erica feeling the positive health effects of singing
story: A NEWCASTLE woman is hitting the high notes with a new Northern Ireland Chest, Heart and Stroke choir.The lsquoInspire Choirrsquo was set up in  and while it initially began as a -week pilot to determine what positive effects singing could have on sufferers of long-term respiratory conditions, it is still going strong three years on and is bigger and better than ever.During lockdown, concerned about the mental and physical effects that shielding was having on its service users, the charity moved the choir online, doubled the rehearsals, and opened it up to all clients.One of the choristers, Erica Gioka mdash a retired art teacher from Newcastle mdash leads an active le visiting friends and family and swimming regularly at the local pool. But lockdown hit her hard.ldquoI live alone, since my husband died, she sadly revealed. ldquoThe house is silent. And although Irsquom a positive person, I get desperately lonely.ldquoBefore lockdown, I had a full schedule. I was driving into Belfast, here, there and everywhere. When lockdown came, there was just nothing.Erica has always suffered with a chronic cough and asthma.She was referred to the charity by the South Eastern Trust respiratory team and joined her local lsquobreathing betterrsquo respiratory support group and took part in their lsquotaking control self-management programmersquo before joining the online inspire choir.ldquoThe pre-singing exercises at choir really help your breathing, something that I struggle with, explained Erica. ldquoKaren, our choir mistress, has trained us to sing several lines of a song in just one breath. It is amazing how much my breathing has improved.And for Erica, the benefits extend beyond respiratory.ldquoThe benefits are tremendous, she continued. ldquoThe choir helps my memory. It makes you feel like you belong to people who care about you.ldquoWhen yoursquore lonely, itrsquos lovely to have a person smiling at you. It relieves stress andyou are depressed, sad or in grief, it helps with that! It gives me so much pleasure and improves how I feel.Eric said she looks at her face before and after the sessions and sees the dference.ldquoMy face had relaxed, my jaw is looser and my eyes are brighter. I am a completely dferent me like a new person. A rejuvenated person, she explained.Erica now looks forward to her weekly choir sessions and she when logs on via Zoom, she opens all the doors in the house ldquoso the music can travel to the furthest corners.She added: ldquoOur leader Karen has such an infectious personality. She is so positive and bright. She greets each one of us by name ndash it makes you feel quite special. I mean, how can you have a glum face when Karen starts singing ldquoShow me the way to Amarillohellip The charityrsquos head of respiratory, Pauline Millar, said the results of the original pilot were nothing short of inspiring.ldquoAfter just  weeks, % of choristers tested found that their speech had improved and % noted a boost in their mental health. Not only that, we saw considerable improvements in the grouprsquos sleeping, anxiety levels, chest tightness and ability to walk, she revealed.ldquoAs well as improving lung , we saw such social and mental health improvement. We knew then that the choir could provide a leline of support for our clients in lockdown.Pauline said the improvement in some of the charityrsquos clients has been incredible, adding: ldquoThey have gone from being extremely breathless, depressed and lonely to coming along to choir with the biggest smiles on their faces.rsquoTo find out more about the charityrsquos care services for local people with chest, heart and stroke disease visit www.nichs.org.uk.prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C April 25%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK ndashDunleath Park could be dramatically redeveloped to provide Downpatrick with a stunning new town park.The proposal is to be investigated by senior Down Council officials who are to compile a detailed report on the implications of such a move and how much it would cost.The suggestion to redevelop the entire park, including surrounding land at the rear of Pemberton Park and adjacent to St Patrickrsquos Avenue, was discussed at Monday nightrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Client Services Committee.The provision of the new park, including walks and planted areas, was proposed by Downpatrick councillor, Mrs Anne Trainor, who believes the sprawling Dunleath Park site has ldquotremendous potential to be transformed into a town park which would be the envy of many areas.She believesfunding could be found, the development would be major asset to the county town.Mrs Trainor has called on the council to work closely with Owenbeg Bowling Club officials, who are currently working up plans to provide new tennis courts beside their premises which border Dunleath.But she has made it clear the redevelopment proposal can only be considereda new home can be found for the existing sports pitches.KILLINCHY ndash A Killinchy factory which faced an uncertain future at the start of the year has won a reprieve.Staff at the Carpets International plant are celebrating confirmation that the factory will not be close as part of a major restructuring and downsizing operation by its American owners.News that the Killinchy plant, which employs  people, is to remain open came on Monday afternoon and was confirmed by senior company officials at the firmrsquos UK headquarters in Bradford.The majority of the staff at the factory are from the Killyleagh and surrounding areas and local councillors and shop stewards are delighted the factory is to continue playing a key role in the carpet manufacturing industry.The major restructuring will involve the closure of two plants in England with the loss of  jobs, but the operation in Killinchy is to remain ldquorelatively unchanged.SHRIGLEY ndash Down councillors have pledged their support to the -strong workforce of the Shrigley firm of International Leathers.The politicians this week said the workers must not become the victims of a major poundm redevelopment of the -acre site of the villagersquos former mill and tannery.The International Leathers factory is located within the redevelopment zone and there has been ongoing concern with the firmrsquos management that its future was being ignored by the business consortium behind the project.Senior managers felt the outline planning application for a mix of housing and small business workspaces did not take into account the existence or future development of International Leathers.KILLYLEAGH ndash Killyleagh police are investigating a spate of animal poisoning incidents which are believed to have claimed the lives of ten dogs.A local vet has confirmed the dogs have been poisoned by paraquat and one local woman has had to bury two dogs which are both believed to have been killed by poisoning.Downpatrick vet, Mr Maurice King, of Downe Veterinary Clinic, has said he has seen four cases of paraquat poisoning and believed there could have been another six cases in the area.All the cases have occurred in the Ardigon and Jericho Road areas of the town.Mrs Elizabeth Grebbell, from Ardigon Road, has seen two of her dogs killed through paraquat poisoning.BALLYHORNAN ndash A major rescue operation which was carried out last week off the Ballyhornan coastline has raised concerns about the seaworthiness of the vessels involved.Tuesday nightrsquos rescue, which cost thousands of pounds, took place as two fishing vessels, one under tow, made their way past Gunns Island at around pm on Tuesday night.The two vessels, the -foot Azure Sea and the -foot Walpaul, had been en route from Howth, near Dundalk to Carrickfergus when the accident occurred around three miles off the mouth of Strangford Lough.The Walpaul had been towing the Azure Sea when the tow line broke and the two vessels collided. The Walpaul started taking water into its engine room and its propeller became snagged as the crews tried to reconnect the two rope.A passing Naval patrol vessel assisted leboats from Newcastle, Portaferry and Donaghadee in the rescue.A search and rescue helicopter was scrambled from Wales, but ed to base as details of the situation became clearer and a Nimrod plane, based at RAF Kinloss in Scotland was also put in standby. Newcastle Coastguard team was also sent to the scene but played no part in the rescue.CASTLEWELLAN ndash Down Districtrsquos economy has suffered a body blow this week with confirmation that one of the largest ever conferences planned for the area has been moved to Belfast.The major Christian conference planned for Castlewellan Forest Park has had to be switched to Belfast as result of the continuing foot and mouth crisis.The organisers of the leading womenrsquos event say they are ldquoextremely disappointed the conference will not go ahead as planned in the grounds of the townrsquos Forest Park and are not optimistic it will come to Down next year.Over , people were expected to take park in the three-day event with visitors coming to the district from across the Province and other parts of the British Isles.The Evangelical Ministries, which had this year decided to hold the event in Castlewellan instead of its traditional base at the University of Ulster in Coleraine, said they had been looking forward to hosting the event in Down District.The grouprsquos chairman, Alison Beasant said everyone in the Castlewellan area had been tremendous in helping organise the event and praised the efforts of the Forest Service and local hotel and guesthouse owners.PORTAFERRY ndash A Strangford Assembly member has this week criticised the slow progress being made on the provision of a new sewage treatment works in Portaferry.Mr Kieran McCarthy said the issue, which topped the agenda at a special meeting in the village earlier this year, is not progressing as quickly as people in the village had hoped.The Assembly member has revealed that following recent talks with Water Service officials, it has been confirmed a detailed study of the new plant had been completed.He also confirmed a further public meeting in Portaferry is to be held shortly to provide local people with an update on the scheme to provide a new treatment plant in the village.KILMORE ndash Members of Kilmore Parish Church could be in line for a major cash windfall from Down Council.The congregation at Christ Church haveapplied to the local authority for landfill tax funding to help with a major scheme which involves repainting and repointing the historic building.The application for the landfill tax funding has been made by the Ulster Wildle Trust on the churchrsquos behalf and the council hopes to make a decision shortly.News of the application was confirmed at Monday nightrsquos meeting of the councilrsquos Client Services Committee when details of the pound, scheme at the Kilmore church were unveiled..prettyPhoto

title: Guided walks along the St Patrick’s Way to resume
story: GUIDED walks along the St Patrickrsquos Way are now on offer from the St Patrick Centre following an easing of the lockdown restrictions.Pilgrims will be able to walk with St Patrickrsquos guides to sites such as Inch Abbey, Saul Church, and Slieve Patrick from next week, starting in Downpatrick from April - and from Newcastle into the Mournes from May .The new St Patrickrsquos coastal route from Ballyhornan to Ardglass, which takes in St Patrickrsquos Well, Sheepland and the ancient ruin at Ardtole, is available twice a month from May .The Camino and Canoe Adventure on the Quoile mdash a guided km water and walking route to Inch Abbey and Saul Church mdash commences on Wednesdays from May .ldquoWe have been working on these new adventures during lockdown, said Dr Tim Campbell, St Patrick Centre director.ldquoWe are delighted to be able to open our doors again to welcome visitors from home and abroad.ldquoThe walks which were piloted last year were really popular and we hope many people will come and walk St Patrickrsquos Way and learn about the true Patrick, a courageous man of faith whose impact is still being felt  years later.ldquoThe new canoeing adventure is amazing. I have walked along the Quoile many times but it is a whole new experience seeing Down Cathedral from the water as a swan lands on the river.Pilgrim guide Martina Purdy said new passports have been printed for Downpatrick, as well as the new coastal route which offers some of the most spectacular coastline in Ireland.ldquoWe have so much beauty on our doorstep and this is a great way to enjoy the countryside, experience the spirit of St Patrick and meet new people, she remarked.ldquoDuring our first season last year, pilgrims came from as far away as Mayo, Louth and Dublin and we are finding there is a lot of interest from people closer to home too.ldquoThe walks are tailored for dferent fitness levels with a gentle six-mile walk along the Quoile or a challenging km walk.Pilgrim guide Elaine Kelly said she was looking forward to welcoming everyone to St Patrickrsquos Way.ldquoWe have a fantastic array of pilgrim experiences that will delight and inspire you, said Ms Kelly, who will be leading the canoeing along with John Hubbocks from Mobile Team Adventure.The St Patrickrsquos Centre Shop and the new look Ryanrsquos Garden Cafeacute are opening on Friday, April .To book St Patrickrsquos Way, contact   , or go online www.saintpatrickcentre..prettyPhoto

title: Harper flies in Germany
story: ANNAHILT racing sensation Daniel Harper recorded an impressive top ten finish in his long-awaited GT category debut for the BMW Junior Team.Highflying Harperwas competing last Saturday in the second event of the  Nuumlrburgring Endurance Series in Germany.The opening round of the season was delayed due to heavy snowfall last month.Harper finally got his first opportunity to race on the world-famous  mile Nuumlrburgring Nordschlee alongside team-mates Max Hesse and Neil Verhagen in their nicknamed lsquoblue rocketrsquo BMW M GT.Harper was able to get crucial mileage in his new car during open practice a day before the event as he eyed further progress in qualying the next day.BMW had to draft in factory driver Augusto Farfus after a technical issue resulted in Harperrsquos team missing out on the majority of the session. However, the Brazillian ace showed his class with a single lap flyer to secure tenth on the grid.ldquoIrsquom super happy with the result. After a few problems with the car on Friday and Saturday, it was a good comeback from the whole team to complete the race as the quickest BMW out there and record a competitive top ten finish said Harper.Farfus began the four-hour race before handing the wheel over to Harper in th place. The BMW team exhibited a dferent pitstop strategy to the rest of the competing teams, which ultimately catapulted Harper to second place.Harper pushed for the provisional race lead as he recorded a very impressive sub-eight minute lap of the Nordschlee, his quickest lap on the course.ldquoWhile the pitstop cycles played into my favour a bit, it was still a great feeling to be up there battling for the race lead at one stage, he said afterwards.ldquoTo have recorded my quickest lap on the Nordschlee so far is a bonus and Irsquoll be pushing to bring that benchmark down.Whilst traffic ultimately cost Harper time in his pursuit of first place, he still remained in second position to the end of his stint. Teammates Hesse and Verhagen took the reins after Harper as the team placed eighth position overall.Harper said: ldquoBMW Team RMG and my team-mates did a fantastic job and wersquore pretty pleased to have shown in our first race in the GT that wersquore capable of running towards the front.ldquoWersquore under no illusions that we still have a lot more progress to make though and wersquore ready for the next race.The next round of the Nuumlrburgring Endurance Series is scheduled to take place on Saturday, May ..prettyPhoto

title: Lauren predicting great things ahead for NI soccer girls
story: BALLYNAHINCH goalkeeper Lauren Perry has said Northern Irelandrsquos women can inspire the next generation after qualying for Euro .Northern Ireland made their first ever major tournament last week after beating Ukraine in the playoffs over two legs, sealing it at Seaview with a - win thanks to goals from captain Marissa Callaghan and Nadene Caldwell.Kenny Shielsrsquo side won the first leg out in Ukraine with goals from Liverpoolrsquos Rachel Furness and Everton striker Simone Magill to take a - lead back to Belfast with them.Perry , who plays for Scottish side Forfar Farmington, wasnrsquot included in the squad for the playoffs but has been involved throughout the Euro  qualication period.ldquoItrsquos surreal that wersquove booked our place in the Euros. Even just saying wersquore going to the Euros is just unbelievable, itrsquos massive for the country, she said.ldquoLooking back ten years ago we wouldnrsquot have been in contention to qualy so just to see the transformation over the years is great. At the start of the campaign we got beat - by Norway and we didnrsquot even bat an eyelid at it we just kept going.ldquoWhen we beat Belarus - we were down to ten players and I think thatrsquos when we started to realise that we could make it happen.Perry started her career at Ballynahinch Youth before moving to Linfield and eventually getting her move across the water to Blackburn Rovers and now Forfar Farmington.The shot-stopper spoke about what qualying for the Euros will do to the future generation of Northern Irish players.We really want to inspire the next generation and make it possible for any girl to go and pick up a pair of football boots or a football shirt and go out to play, that was the main thing for us, she said.ldquoBut even in terms of the older players that are maybe towards the end of their career, to be role models for the younger ones coming through is just great to see.Northern Ireland are the second smallest nation to qualy for the Womenrsquos Euros with Iceland being the first. Many of the Northern Irish players playing in the local Irish League have only had just one match since December, which was against England in February.ldquoWe have a lot of players that go and do their nine to five jobs and then come to training, theyrsquove dedicated themselves to that, said Perry.ldquoEspecially the older ones, as for the younger ones like myself wersquore pushing through and hopefully get across the water, she added.ldquoThe league in Northern Ireland is good but itrsquos not as competitive as the league here in Scotland or in England.Perry has been a consistent performer for Forfar Farmington since signing from Rovers and she hopes to be rejoining the National team for next yearrsquos Euros.ldquoI need to keep doing what I am doing. Irsquom enjoying my football at the minute and playing week in, week out is something I hope I can continue to do and continue to perform then Irsquoll catch the eye of Kenny Shiels again and hopefully come next summer Irsquoll be on that plane.ldquoAt Forfar Farmington I get tested week in, week out. I go into every game knowing that Irsquom going to have to do something and that Irsquom going to have to be on top form which is good for me because it means I canrsquot switch off and have to be ready each week she added.Of Shiels, who has led Northern Irelandrsquos women to their first major tournament, she says: ldquoHersquos changed the way we play, wersquore playing with a lot more confidence. We are a lot more confident on the ball, beforehand we would have just kicked it up the pitch and get a two second breather and wersquore back to defending said the Ballynahinch goalkeeper.ldquoBut now wersquore just so confident and everyone is enjoying their football. Alfie Wylie did great things for the team but I think Kenny coming in has just freshened it up and it gave everyone that sense of we can achieve something she added.On Friday it was announced that Northern Ireland had moved up to th in the FIFA World rankings which is the highest theyrsquove ever been.The delighted Perry said: ldquoItrsquos massive for Northern Ireland, we beat Ukraine by a good gap overall as it was - but they were th or something like that ranked.ldquoSo just beating teams like that just shows how we are progressing and I think now itrsquos what we deserve and hopefully over the coming years we can progress she added.Northern Ireland have played their games at Seaview, home of Crusaders, for the last few years, but following the qualication it was mentioned about Windsor Park being the venue for future fixtures.ldquoIrsquove played at Windsor Park once and itrsquos so big. Seaview probably suits us better and it saves our legs said Perry.ldquoWindsor Park is the home of Northern Ireland football and it would mean a lot for the girls who havenrsquot played there to eventually step on that pitch and get a game representing their country on the pitch that the men play on.Shiels recently commented the win was the best sporting achievement in UK history due to the fact amateur players had beaten professionals throughout the game.ldquoItrsquos a huge statement to come out with but I think part of it is true because nobody would ever have expected little Northern Ireland to qualy for the Euros said Perry.ldquoNobody would have have looked at us before and said that we are going to qualy. However, I now hope people start to look at us and begin to realise that Northern Ireland are progressing and getting places.Perry made headlines at the weekend as she scored a dramatic last minute equaliser in Forfar Farmingtonrsquos - draw with Hearts. The goalkeeper scored a free-kick from  yards out in the last minute of the match to earn her side a point..prettyPhoto

title: Lewis ‘shocked%2C but not surprised’ at repeated dumping
story: ONE of the districtrsquos beauty spots is falling prey to illegal dumpers.The area around Spa Lake, near Ballynahinch, has been the site of repeated instances of dumping recently.Last week a discarded settee and rubbish was found in the area.The latest incident has been condemned by local councillor Alan Lewis, who says the dumpers are showing ldquotwo fingers to the community.Cllr Lewis said the incident occurred last Friday, ironically just hours after he had launched a Neighbourhood Watch scheme in the Spa area.ldquoI was absolutely astounded to receive photos of this dumping it occurred in broad daylight, literally hours after I left the area, he said.ldquoIrsquom shocked though, unfortunately, not surprised. This wilful dumping reflects a serious discourtesy and unbelievable laziness.ldquoThis is another in a long list of incidents at Spa Lake. Just last week our team removed tyres and a washing machine.ldquoThe week before I had organised a litter-pick and residents removed a car bumper and bags of rubbish.ldquoItrsquos unacceptable, beneath contempt. Those responsible are burdens to society and an embarrassment to the community.He continued: ldquoI often wonder at the type of person who would care so less about the countryside and community they live in to dump on the side of the road. Their actions reflect their intelligence and lack of belonging within the area.Cllr Lewis says he has received dash cam which, he believes, may track down the culprits.ldquoThe wannabe film stars can expect a knock on the door from our council enforcement team, he continued.ldquoThere is simply no excuse, absolutely none. Those who do this need fined. We should work toward increasing those fines, ensuring that the punishment matches the offence.ldquoThe time and energy that it takes council staff clearing this up is staggering. Our staff simply have better things to be at that clearing up after laziness and stupidity.ldquoThe household recycling centres are open six days a week. There is one a few miles down the road in Ballynahinch. Those responsible should educate themselves it would have saved them the bother of fly-tipping.ldquoNeighbourhood services should also look at permitting vans to enter or HRCs, I accept the rule prevents commercial use. However, there is a danger we are penalising residents who would dispose responsibility while facilitating an excuse for those who donrsquot.Cllr Lewis added: ldquoI fear my work in highlighting these through the pages of our local press facilitates oxygen to these morons, but I believe councillors have a duty to call it out, while continuing to lobby for suitable and stringent fines..prettyPhoto

title: Lorna on the merits of open sea swimming
story: A KILLYLEAGH woman has praised the benefits of open water swimming and how it has helped her cope through the lockdown.Lorna McCormick,has noticed a substantial increase in people taking part in cold water swimming during the last year amidst the pandemic.Lorna credits swimming in cold water to benefiting her own health, as she first experienced when she started three years ago.ldquoI think one of the reasons I got into cold water swimming was for my own health. I had been told it was good for anxiety which I have struggled with, so I thought I may try it myself, said Lorna.ldquoOnce I tried it for the first time, I was hooked. It sends sensations up your body and brings an overwhelming sense of calmness to you. Itrsquos a complete form of tranquility.Cold water swimming has been reported to help people who struggle with depression and anxiety as well as slowing down the onset of dementia and help with the effects of menopause. It also has been reported to increase happiness, give your body better circulation and to help build your immune system.Although an advocate for cold water, Lorna also stressed the importance of safe swimming, especially when the temperature s to near freezing.ldquoItrsquos a good place to be when yoursquore in the water. I think the colder it is then the more benefit you get from it, she said. ldquoHowever, you obviously have to be careful when yoursquore going in, especially during harsher weather you have to limit your time.ldquoIf you go into it and yoursquore not used to having your breathing under control, your body can go into an uncontrollable shock. Start slowly and get your body into control. Irsquove seen people walk in and run out again almost immediately, but once you get used to the process you just feel happy, calm and relaxed and you want to stay in longer.After stressing iables which must be taken into account before hitting the waters, Lorna also lists some essential tips for beginners thinking of giving it a try.ldquoAlways take someone with you in case something goes wrong. Try and find a safe beach, which I know could be more challenging as we have to stay local she said.Since lockdown, Irsquove been restricted so I would travel to the end of the quay in Killyleagh and swim down there. You have to consider the effects of rip tides as they can come close to the shore and can be a very real danger.Lorna recommends those who are thinking of giving it a try to bring a wetsuit, neoprene socks, a hat, gloves, dry robe, hot drinks and possibly a hot water bottle for afterwards.Swimmers should always aim to gradually heat their body once out of the water by adding layers to prevent going into a hypothermic shock.Also, they are advised to bring a floating aid to be seen safely and wear bright clothes.Lorna, a NHS care worker, first got involved with wild swimming after a colleague informed her of a Bangor-based group called Dash and Splash.Since then, more and more groups have took to the waters in local places such as Newcastle, Ballyhornan and Whiterock. Lornarsquos native Killyleagh have recently formed the cold water group Dippy Flipper swimmers.These groups are highly recommended to beginners as they have invaluable knowledge of the waters they are swimming in..prettyPhoto

title: Methodist church in Downpatrick closes
story: THE doors at Downpatrick Methodist Church shut for the last time at the weekend.The church at the junction of Saul Street and Scotch Street officially closed on Sunday, marking the end of a long chapter of active Methodist church le in the town.Methodism in Downpatrick goes back to the days of John Wesley, who visited the town four times in , ,  and .On each occasion he preached in the Grove at the foot of Down Cathedral and in  a memorial stone was placed at the spot to commemorate those visits and the contribution of Methodism to Irish le.A year before Wesleyrsquos first visit the original Methodist preaching house in the town was opened at Scotch Street by the Rev Edward Smyth, an Anglican clergyman who left his curacy at Ballyculter to become a Methodist preacher. He and his we, Agnes, began to hold services in Downpatrick and surrounding neighbourhood, preaching, holding society meetings and administering the sacraments.He went on to build a Methodist preaching house in the town, personally raising funds, obtaining a suitable site and even joining in manual labour to ensure its completion.He conducted the opening service on November , , at Scotch Street and he and his family moved into an adjoining small room, which for many years afterwards served to accommodate preachers appointed to the town.It was decided in  to replace the original building with a new one on the same site. The result was the present building which was opened in April  at a cost of pound,.The congregation at the time decided to use chairs rather than pews in their new worship centre so that the building could be used for youth work and other activities during the week.In , the congregation completed an extension to the building in the form of a new kitchen and toilet facilities as well as a large upper room for youth work and other community activities. The cost of was pound, all of which was met by the local congregation.Whilst the Methodist congregation in Downpatrick has always been relatively small it has nevertheless made enormous contributions to religious, civil, and civic le in the town and surrounding area.There are strong ecumenical relations dating back to its inception as a church body. The congregation has endeavoured to work alongside denominations and the church was used as a refreshment point on the annual St Patrickrsquos Day pilgrimage from Saul to Down Cathedral where pilgrims were treated to a potted history of Methodism by Dr Brian Turner.The congregation also hosted well renowned annual lectures by visiting speakers including Baroness Blood and the distinguished author and journalist Alf McCreary, among others. In more recent years the dwindling congregation began to consider its future as part of the Dundrum, Newcastle and Downpatrick Methodist Circuit.All three congregations have suffered losses over the last two decades and it was time to consider how the Methodist community in southeast Down might look in the future.In January of  following several discussions with all three congregations the Circuit Council took the dficult decision to close Downpatrick and Dundrum Methodist Churches and consolidate as one congregation under the new name of Donard Methodist Church which meets in the Newcastle Methodist Church building.The Rev Mervyn Ewing, circuit minister, said: ldquoClosing a church is a huge and dficult decision to make which members of the Circuit Council did not make lightly.ldquoIt is important to note the considerable sacrices that were made over the years by the Downpatrick people who were committed and devoted to God, one another and their church.ldquoWe are very conscious of the emotional cost this decision has exacted on the devoted congregation. As Christians we believe firmly in resurrection for something new to grow and flourish there must be death.ldquoAs Methodists, building on all that has been before and what we have learned from one another and God, we forge ahead believing that in the lsquoNew Thingrsquo God creates there will be le and energy to stay true to our Methodist calling.Since the present Downpatrick Methodist Church was opened in  the ministers in charge have been as follows:, John McCaffrey, BA , John Hart , William E. Cullen, BA, , William Warren, BA, BSc , Thomas Kennedy , John J. Harrison , Malcolm E.G. Redman , N. Cyril Haire , Morris Matthis, Jerre Nolte, D. Alfred R. Skuce , John R. Brookes , William J. Mackay , Dr. J. Stanley McQuade , Ross J. Harte, LI.B, MDiv , Kenneth Connor, BA, Fd.A , E. Louise Mc Kee BTh, MTh , Mervyn Ewing BTh, and Thomas Clarke BA..prettyPhoto

title: More tyres uncovered in latest dumping incident
story: ANOTHER consignment of dumped tyres has been found on the outskirts of Killyleagh.The latest batch at the Scaddy Road was discovered last Thursday afternoon by Rowallane councillor Terry Andrews while he was out walking in the area.Over recent weeks, dumped tyres have been uncovered at the Wallace Hill Road outside Killyleagh, while earlier in the year a number were discovered during separate incidents near Ballynahinch and Saintfield.Cllr Andrews said given the worrying number of incidents the issue needs to be addressed, appealing to anyone who spots any suspicious activity mdash especially in isolated rural areas mdash to contact police.He said there have been previous tyre dumping incidents at the Scaddy Road and is concerned that what is an environmental crime, is on the rise in certain parts of the district.ldquoAnyone who can help identy the illegal dumpers must come forward as this despicable behaviour must not be allowed to continue, declared Cllr Andrews. ldquoAs has been said many times before by myself and other Newry, Mourne and Down councillors, there is simply no excuse for this kind of behaviour.ldquoIllegal dumping is unacceptable and many will be worried that this crime is on the rise. The question is, who is responsible  Is it the same person or a number of people involved Cllr Andrews said that illegal dumping and so-called fly-tipping was a ldquoblight on the landscape, questioning the mentality of those who engage in such behaviour.ldquoPeople who choose secluded rural areas to get rid of their waste need to face the full force of the law, he declared. ldquoI cannot understand the mentality of those who involve themselves in this behaviour and who display a blatant disregard for the area.Cllr Andrews said while the overwhelming majority of the districtrsquos residents use the facilities available to them to dispose of their waste, others view rural areas as open air dumping grounds.He said there were civic amenity sites in Downpatrick, Ballynahinch and Castlewellan to enable people to get rid of their waste, with Newry, Mourne and Down Council also offering a home bulky refuse collection service.Cllr Andrews continued: ldquoPeople need to show the countryside more respect. Illegal dumping is an environmental crime which must cease. It really beggars belief that there are those who prefer to drive to rural locations to get rid of their waste rather disposing of it properly.ldquoThere is a cost associated with removing waste which, more often than not, is borne by hard-pressed ratepayers. Illegal dumping is an issue the district needs to get a grip on.The Rowallane councillor added: ldquoThis behaviour is unacceptable and must cease. There is simply no excuse for it.Newry, Mourne and Down Council revealed recently that that there has been a % increase in fly-tipping incidents across the council area, with  reported cases between  and ..prettyPhoto

title: New speed sign in Ardglass welcomed by local politicians
story: THE provision of a new electronic speed indicator sign at the Downpatrick Road in Ardglass has been welcomed by two politicians.Downpatrick area councillors Dermot Curran and Oonagh Hanlon mdash who have been campaigning for the device ndash are confident that it will reduce speed at the entrance to the village and help enhance road safety.Cllr Curran says he has been concerned about the speeding issue at this part of the village for some time and is pleased that the new sign, funded by the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership , is now in place.He said the speeding issue had been raised with him on a number of occasions, particularly on the approach to St Nicholasrsquo Primary School.ldquoI have raised my concern with the Department for Infrastructureand the PCSP am pleased that Ardglass is one of seven new locations earmarked for the speed indicator signs. I hope that it will make a dference, continued Cllr Curran.ldquoIt is important that drivers are aware of their speed at all times, especially in built-up areas. If an area is restricted to mph for example, drivers should actually be travelling below this speed.Cllr Curran said it was in everyonersquos interest that drivers obey the law and adhere to speed limits which are in place for a reason.He added: ldquoIt is my understanding that Downpatrick Road residents in Ardglass have already noticed a decrease in the speed of passing vehicles which is particularly welcome.Cllr Hanlon said she has also been informed by residents that there has been a noticeable decrease in speed since the new sign was erected.ldquoAs a PCSP member I have continually highlighted the need for speed calming measures throughout the Downpatrick and Lecale area and attended a recent site meeting with PCSP staff, PSNI and DfI officials when the location of the sign at the Downpatrick Road in Ardglass was agreed, she said.ldquoThis particular stretch of road has been an area of concern for many years. It it is a busy residential area and leads in to St Nicholasrsquo Primary.ldquoThe concern for the safety of pupils, staff and residents has been brought to my attention many times as lives were being placed at risk such is the speed of some motorists.Cllr Hanlon said the PCSP deserved credit for listening to the concerns of elected representatives and the wider public on the speeding issue.She said the message which must go out is that speeders are placing their lives and those of other road users in danger.She added: ldquoI appeal to all drivers is to obey the speed restrictions in place and drive within them.ldquoThe further roll-out of speed indicator signs has opened the debate and the need for devices in other areas. I have been inundated with requests and will continue to lobby for other areas of need for future roll outs.Cllr Hanlon said seven of the new signs will be erected shortly across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area as part of the major clampdown on speeders..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle Mass Pad reopens
story: THE reopening of the Mass Pad at Newcastlersquos King Street has been welcomed by local councillor Willie Clarke.The pathway mdash which leads to the Mass Rock located in a garden in the area ndash had become overgrown and was inaccessible for the public, resulting in its closure for  years. But it has now reopened.Cllr Clarke described the path and associated Mass Rock as an ldquointeresting and subtle historical reminder of Penal times, from around  until  in Ireland when Catholics and other non lsquoestablishedrsquo religions were not permitted to practice their religion under Penal Laws.As a result, he revealed that mass was often said in secluded outdoor locations, such as King Street.ldquoThis simple feature is a signicant symbol and reminder of the repression of the Irish Catholics during the Penal Laws in the th century, said Cllr Clarke.He added: ldquoIt is also an interesting addition to the heritage of the area and Sinn Feacutein members, along with local residents, decided to make the site more accessible to provide a historic amenity for the local population and visitors..prettyPhoto

title: Praise for pharmacies in jab roll out
story: THE key role played by community pharmacies across the district in response to the coronavirus pandemic has been praised by a local politician.Many pharmacies are now offering Covid vaccinations as part of the province-wide roll-out programme with Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis thanking community pharmacy staff for their continued effort and commitment.He said staff ldquoadapted and continued to serve our community during the toughest days of lockdown and revealed that he recently visited Clough pharmacy to extend a personal thanks to staff.Cllr Lewis said that community pharmacies joined the Covid- vaccination programme from the end of March and are continuing to deliver frontline health care.ldquoPharmacists tell me that they are ready and willing to play their part, he continued. ldquoHealth minister Robin Swann is in listening mode and has taken every opportunity to engage with pro-active ways to get the vaccine rolled out.ldquoThe plan has seen hundreds of community pharmacies provide vaccinations to the public, complementing the work of GP practices and vaccination centres. Over  pharmacies have signed up to be part of the scheme to date.rsquoCllr Lewis said he is delighted that Clough pharmacy is now part of the vaccination programme ldquobringing the le-saving vaccination drive to many high streets, urban and rural neighbourhoods. He also revealed that last Saturday, almost  patients were booked in to have their jab.ldquoCommunity pharmacists are an integral part of the health and social care family, said Cllr Lewis. ldquoTheir contribution to getting as many people vaccinated as possible will be invaluable.ldquoThroughout the pandemic, the community pharmacy workforce has gone above and beyond to support patients across Northern Ireland. This latest example shows our pharmacists collaborating to ensure a smooth and safe vaccine programme to protect the public. This should be commended.Cllr Lewis said the new vaccination initiative will provide a convenient, localised service, with eligible members of the public receiving their jabs in scheduled clinics.He said for a iety of reasons, there are those who cannot attend mass vaccination centres, such as the SSE in Belfast.ldquoIt is vital that our population has every opportunity to access the vaccination service and itrsquos fantastic to have over  further points where people can book an appointment for a vaccine within their own village, town or community at a time and a place that suits them, he said.Cllr Lewis added: ldquoI would encourage residents to contact their local pharmacy to check availability and book their vaccine now..prettyPhoto

title: Shimna College students take part in Dundrum club coaching scheme
story: DUNDRUM Cricket Club have struck up a partnership with Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle last week.The cricket club have begun a weekly coaching programme at the school in order to get more young people introduced to the sport.Club stalwart Jeff Maguire said: ldquoThe boys and girls really loved it. Itrsquos a big thing for our club that we have a school on our doorstep full of pupils with potential, wanting to learn the great sport of cricket.He continued: ldquoIf you provide the training the kids will love it, there were over  participants in each of the sessions.The cricket club have big plans for the future ahead as they hope to enter more local schools in the future.ldquoWe are targeting other schools to teach as many people as possible, Jeff continued. ldquoWe hope there will be a primary school tournament day in the future with at least six dferent schools taking part.ldquoIf the kids want to join the club after seeing what the sport is like then thatrsquos fantastic, but the priority is that they have fun.Coaching is under the supervision of Dundrumrsquos new player coach, Daniel Kearsley.Keearsley is a level two cricket coach, who has had trials with Warwickshire and Nottinghamshire. He will also be the new head coach for the clubrsquos juniors.ldquoDaniel is here on a two-year contract. He wants sustainability with the schools and juniors. He has been superb thus far, showing great enthusiasm in his teaching, setting out drills and interacting with students, said Jeff.The club is very excited to get back playing and are hopeful for ato play next month.If anyone is interested in joining the club they should get in contact via they clubrsquos Facebook page..prettyPhoto

title: Strangford ace is much missed
story: NOEL Breen, who died on April , was a true table tennis legend.Known affectionately throughout the table tennis fraternity as lsquoChopperrsquo, Noel was a member of Strangford Table Tennis Club for over  years and made a sufficient contribution in making the club the most successful in the history of the Lecale table Tennis league.The Strangford club of the s had finally ended the domination of St Patrickrsquos and Castlewellan and in  won all league and inidual titles.When I joined the club Noel was already an established player. I watched the tall athletic figureballs with a hard bat, as they were known, while most in the club were playing with the new sponge covered weapons. I immediately decided that was the type of style and bat I wanted to play with.It was an exciting time in the club for young hopefuls eager to impress the boss, Leslie Sullivan, and get a place in of the three teams competing in the league. When I was eventually told that I would be playing in the A team away to St Maryrsquos, Newcastle, and partnering Noel in the doubles I was so excited that I practiced every night in preparation for the match which we won and then had to thumb a lt home.It was the start of a long tournament doubles partnership. We may not have been the most successful mdash our styles were too similar for that mdash but we certainly made the opposition work for every point.By the late s reverse bats, as they were known, were now the preferred option for most players, but Noelrsquos long range chopped defence suited the pimpled bat known as the lsquoBarnarsquo, named after  times world champion Victor Barna, and the perfect foil toto loop drives created by the new sponge revolution.The matches between Noel and his attacking opponents were a joy to watch and earned him the nickname Chopper. But soon new defensive products arrived, making Noel an even a more dficult player to contend with and resulted in him winning inidual trophies.Opponents who had played him previously knew what to expect and those who didnrsquot soon realised that they had to earn every point as the ball kept coming back mixed with the occasional well-judged forehand kill. All his matches were the same mdash succeed or fail, no quarter asked for and certainly none given.Noel Breen leaves behind a legacy of loyalty and dedication to the sport of table tennis.Always among the first to enter the leaguersquos charity events, he gave up his time to coach the Downpatrick Special Olympics team to compete in the league and helped other clubs in the district when they needed players.But it was at the Strangford club where he started and ended a long and distinguished service as a player and committee member. Whenever he was needed he was always available. He put up tables for competitions, made iders to separate tables and even secured sponsorship from local businesses to pay for the materials.A few years ago he told me he was advised to retire due to health issues. But following a short rest period he ed to support the club due to falling membership. Once a table tennis player always a table tennis player.His passing leaves another void in the golden years of the Lecale League. His affable personality endeared him to all who knew him, as evidenced by the numerous comments posted on social media sites following the news of his death.One especially from Martin Pickles is worthy of mention. He posted that Noel was a great competitor and played a good game of table tennis mdash high praise indeed from the master of defence, and a perfect epitaph to conclude this tribute to my good friend and mentor. Thanks for the memories and the craic Chopper.With deepest sympathy to his we Mary, daughters Noeleen and Carol, son Paul and family circle.By Jim Ritchie, secretary of the Lecale Table Tennis League and chairman of Strangford Table Tennis Club..prettyPhoto

title: Three year wait for new bypass
story: WORK on Ballynahinchrsquos new multi-million pound bypass may not be completed until the spring of  at the earliest.The news has been confirmed this week by the Department for Infrastructure which has revealed that work on the eagerly-awaited scheme is not expected to start for another  months.Construction work on the largest ever road scheme proposed for the district mdash which could cost up to poundm mdash is expected to take an additional  months to complete,funding is made available.The update on the proposed schemersquos timetable comes after Stormont roads minister Nichola Mallon confirmed on Monday that she intends to make a so-called direction order for the near two-mile bypass linking the Newcastle and Belfast roads.Direction orders designate theof proposed road schemes with the roads minister reaffirmingher commitment to the delivery of the Ballynahinch proposal when funding becomes available.The bypass is designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town, with a number of politicians seeking confirmation that money for the scheme will be allocated.They are also demanding to know when construction work will start given the importance of the scheme to address chronic traffic congestion and help revive the market townrsquos economic fortunes.Speculation had been mounting that work on the eagerly-awaited scheme could potentially begin sometime this year given that the project is shovel ready. However, that is not going to happen given the update provided by the government department last night.The roads minister said the important project will deliver a bypass that will ldquosignicantly reduce traffic in the centre of Ballynahinch and improve journey time reliability and safety on the main Belfast to Newcastle Road.In addition to making a direction order, Mrs Mallon has confirmed that her department is currently exploring further opportunities to improve Ballynahinch town centre to create a ldquosustainable, liveable place where people have the space to stay, meet, shop and safely walk, wheel and cycle.She explained this will include opportunities for active and sustainable travel in the town including a new footway cycleway and a park and share facility along the route of the bypass.ldquoWe have a real opportunity to seize this chance for change and build back better together for our local communities, the roads minister declared. ldquoAs Minister, Irsquom committed to making progress in Ballynahinch and right across the North.ldquoThis is a positive step forward for the local community who have waited many years for progress on the Ballynahinch bypass and moving forward with it is part of my plan to aid economic recovery and community transformation, while addressing regional imbalance.Confirmation of the direction order comes after roads officials released a computer generated image on the Department for Infrastructure website which provides an aerial fly-through of the new road scheme, beginning at the Newcastle Road end.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the by-pass where the major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.Roads officials insist that the Ballynahinch scheme will reduce journey times and improve road safety, while politicians urging the roads minister to confirm an early start date for the eagerly-awaited scheme are confident that it can play a key role in the economic regeneration of the market town.A Department for Infrastructure spokesman said last night: ldquoIt is estimated that it would take around  months to the start of construction from any decision to move to procurement and a further  months to construct the scheme subject to funding..prettyPhoto

title: Young Irish dancers make a return to toe tapping action
story: THE easing of restrictions afforded dancers from then locally-based Brennan Miskelly McCormick School of Irish Dancing toto outdoor classes last week.The school, which normally hosts classes in Downpatrick, Crossgar, Teconnaught and Castlewellan, was delighted to get back in action following five months of lockdown and online zoom classes.The week culminated in a presentation of certicates to the dancers who competed at an online feis run by An Comhairle Uladh.The school entered  dancers in this first ever online feis. It was a new and exciting experience for teachers, parents and dancers alike and the school is delighted with its results. Every child entered clinched a coveted sash and many dancers attained a top three placing.The class had entries in every age group. Results were fantastic with grade winners in ious competitions being promoted to the next level.Principal teacher Josephine Brennan King said: ldquoAll our preliminary and championship dancers made the podium places with entries for the feis far exceeding anyonersquos expectations.ldquoWe are so proud of our dancers. They have displayed fantastic resilience in unprecedented times.ldquoEach child has continued to dance and improve. It is so good to see everyone again andto class, albeit outdoors. Whilst on line classes filled the void, there is nothing that comes close to dancing together.ldquoWe have been overwhelmed with the kind messages from parents and are looking forward to a fun packed dancing calendar.During lockdown many of the dancers were also afforded a unique opportunity to collaborate with three-time world champion David Geaney.Following a two hour on-line workshop, dancers were given new material to perfect at home and then upload. The collaboration included dancers from all over Ulster and featured  members of our class.The dancers enjoyed the experience and were delighted to see the final collaboration video on An Comhairle Uladhrsquos Facebook and Instagram pages.Following on from all this hard work dancers were rewarded for their dedication and commitment to the class with ice cream from Brennanrsquos.For further information on classes please contact Christine McCormick   or message the schoolrsquos Facebook and Instagram pages..prettyPhoto

title: northern ireland vaccination programme continues pace
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPatricia Donnelly, head of NIrsquos vaccination programme, said: ldquoOur vaccination programme continues to make signicant progress. The latest figures show that .% of people aged  and over have received their first vaccination. This means that those age groups most vulnerable to this virus will now have some level of protection. The positive news continues when we look at the overall adult population and see that well over half of our adult population have received their first vaccine and almost , people have received both doses.ldquoThe pace at which we have been able to move through the cohorts and our ability to extend eligibility to a number of groups ahead of the original schedule is very welcome. But we must remain mindful that future progress is dependent on vaccine supply.ldquoCurrently anyone over  is eligible for vaccination, with slots mainly available at the SSE Arena although additional slots at other vaccination centres should be available shortly. There is no need to wait for an invitation, I would encourage people not to delay and book an appointment today. The sooner you get your vaccination, the sooner you will be able to benefit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. Cows grazed outdoors using a Lely Grazeway This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
