title: griffin books shortlisted jhalak prize bookshop champion
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityTo mark their fth anniversary,JhalakPrizehave announced a new initiative supported byNational Book Tokenswhereby  independent bookshops will serve asJhalakPrize Bookshop Championsto celebrate one of the  titles shortlisted for theJhalakPrizeBook of the Year by a Writer of Colourand the inauguralJhalakChildrenrsquos andYoung Adult Prize.The participating bookshops are: Pages of Hackney , Grfin Books , Mostly Books , Newham Bookshop , October Books , Lighthouse Books , Round Table Books , Five Leaves Bookshop , Storysmith , The Hastings Bookshop , La Bibliotekaand Childrenrsquos Bookshop .Each shop will champion their title instore and online with bespoke activities such as events, displays, social outreach, onlinecontent such as videos and author QAs.Mel Grfin said:"We are delighted to be associated with the Jhalak Prize, which showcases the writing of British UK resident authors of colour, historically under-represented in the publishing industry."All the shortlisted titles are available from us, and we are pleased to be championing one of the titles in particular, Inferno by Catherine Cho. This powerful account of the authors experience of post-natal psychosis is both moving and harrowing, yet ultimately full of hope."Their locations y from busy city centres to local high streets and places where bookshops might not traditionally be found, such as food courts and markets - with Grfin Books located in Windsor Arcade.MORE NEWS:What all of the shops have in common is a mission to be friendly, welcoming and inclusive spaces at the heart of the local communities they serve and apassion for supporting marginalised voices and creating a readership for their books.     Below is a list ofJhalakPrize shortlisted titles and the bookshops who will champion them.Six books were selected for each Prize with poetry, memoir, young adult fiction and picture books represented in fearless explorations of character and self, using history, folklore, Covid-, mental health and sexuality as inspiration.Each of the shortlist titles was praised for lsquocourageously shininga light on aspects of human experience that often remain hidden.rsquoTheJhalakBook of the Year by a Writer of Colour  Shortlist and Bookshop Champion: article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: dyfri owen increase graffiti tagging penarth
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityDyfri Owen, director of PenarthPhysiotherapy Practice andPilates Studio, has had a sign advertising his studio, just off Victoria Bridge in the town centre tagged recently.ldquoThere seems to be signicantly more graffiti in our town recently,rsquorsquohe said.ldquoNot only does it look unsightly but there will be an expense to my small business to either clean it or replace it and small businesses are already struggling due to the pandemic.ldquoFortunately, most of it appears to be on derelict buildings and things like BT Openreach hubs rather than small business premises and residential houses.ldquoI will remove the graffiti from my sign and replace the signrequired because it obviously looks unsightly for our neighbours, spoils the aesthetics of the town centre and potentially has a negative impact on how my practice is viewed.The sign is just off Victoria BridgeldquoHowever, our sign can still be clearly read by our patients and potential future patients and in a way the perpetrator has successfully drawn more attention to myPhysiotherapy andPilates business as many people have contacted us to inform us about the vandalism and to pass on their commiserations.rsquorsquoMr Owen is aware that evenhe replaces the sign, there is the chance that this could happen again, but said: ldquoYou cannot spend your le worrying about that, you have to do the right thing for the appearance of the town centre.MORE NEWS:ldquoI do not feel angry towards the iniduals who are spraying graffiti all over Penarth town centre.ldquoI actually feel very sorry for them. They must live very boring, unfulfilling lives.     ldquoIt must be awfulthe most fun you can think of having and the most productive thing you can think of to do with your time is to sprayyour name on someone s property.ldquoWhen they eventually mature and develop a conscience, they will look back and regret the things they had previously done and the amount of time they wasted doing these selfish and unnecessarythings.rsquorsquoPenarthPhysiotherapy Practiceand Pilates Studio was established on Windsor Road in . It moved to The Courtyard in Penarth TownCentre in October .Its Director, Dyfri Owen has worked asPhysiotherapistto Cardf Rugby Club for the past  years and asPhysiotherapist to the Football Association of Wales for the past  years.They also provide Physiotherapist-led Pilates classes and they have created a large, loyal Pilates community within Penarth.Their Pilates classes have been on Zoom for the past year but they look forward to welcoming their clients back to the Courtyard Pilates Studio in the near future. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff grounds not location hinkley point dredging
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe dredger vessels ndash which were used during the first phase of dredging in  - are docked in Barry awaiting approval for to begin their work.EDF Energy, who are running the Hinkley Point C development, have confirmed they have booked the vessels in anticipation of a dredging and depositing licence being granted for Portishead but they have not made an application for a licence for this to be done in Cardf Grounds. If they do decide to make the application, it would go to a public consultation ndash which has been completed for Portishead.MORE NEWS:Grfin Books becomes Jhalak Prize Champion - what it means for the shopSome have called for Covid- vaccine to be mandatory for care home staffMore time to share views on the future of Penarth PavilionChris Fayers, head of environment at Hinkley Point C, said: "We have made an application to dredge and then deposit mud at Portishead and are awaiting a decision. We have also submitted an application for Cardf Grounds. The decision on which licensed disposal site will be used is driven by regulatory approval and project schedule."For this second phase of dredging, the UK Government marine scientic agencywent further than before, testing the mud beyond internationally recognised best practice, with more samples at greater depth and with a greater range of analysis. The results confirm previous analysis that the mud is perfectly safe for disposal at sea and poses no risk to humans or the environment."The vessels are arriving in preparation for our planned marine works. Works will only commence when the appropriate licences have been granted by the regulator." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ruth dodsworth speaks abusive relationship morning
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMs Dodsworth was stalked by her husband Jonathan Wignall, who jailed last week for three years.Speaking on ITVs This Morning about years spent being coercively controlled by Wignall, she said that the details of her case were never meant to be public."Suddenly they were out there when Jonathan was sentenced," she said."The decision to go public was almost taken away from me."The pair had been married for  years and Ms Dodsworth - a regular ITV weather presenter on regional news in Wales and London ndash said that "within a marriage, at first, you try to make it work"."You make excuses, you put on this smile," she said.However, she said that with the benefit of hindsight, all the signs were there."We were happy, but there were instances where his temper was obvious," she said."As things started to fall down, I became the focus of his temper, his anger."The very phrase lsquodomestic abusersquo or lsquocoercive controlrsquo I find quite dficult to say because, for a long time I didnrsquot recognise or put myself in that category."She explained that around two years ago things began to escalate signicantly."He had been phoning me hundreds and hundreds of times a day and turning up at the office," she said."One particular day he had started drinking early in the day. By the time my children got home from school they were phoning me saying ldquomum, donrsquot come home. Hersquos going to kill you."That was a turning point. I didnrsquot go home that night. If I had, I donrsquot think I would be here now."Ms Dodsworth explained how, while she was sleeping, Wignall, now of Trawler Road, Swansea, held her thumb on her phone so that he could gain access to it.He also stood outside the bathroom door while she was in there."To him, every male I met was a potential affair," she said.     "He offered to pay my children money to go into my phone."He put a tracker on my car, which we only noticed after he started turning up in places he had no reason to be."This is a man I loved, and who was father to my children."She said that it took someone  saying ldquoRuthyou donrsquot phone the police, I will, to change the situation."When yoursquore in that situation itrsquos degrading, dehumanising," she said."I wouldnrsquot be aliveI hadnrsquot asked for help." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: expect penarth pub gardens reopen monday
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPub-goers have waited months for this day, and now they will be allowed to have a pint outdoors as coronavirus rates drop.Hayley Clare, bar manager, and Stephen Newman, chairman, at Penarth Athletic Club said that they have been lsquobusyrsquo setting up the outdoor pub garden ready for when they can welcome back customers and members on Monday.They will also be hosting a iety of local businesses to use their kitchen to cook food for those attending, such as Crepe Escape and Onzon Thai.Speaking about the past year, Ms Clare, who started working at the club in September of last year, said that they took the lockdowns as their opportunity to look at where they were, what they were doing and make some changes as there were some issues with parts of the building and they were granted the time to upgrade.Hayley and StephenThe current Welsh Government law only allows hospitality to open outside, and the club has a big space of green land to make use of which can host around  people - but only two households per table.Marquees are also being installed to create some shelter in case the weather decides to change.Mr Newman has described the past year as lsquomadnessrsquo, and that theyrsquod never realised lsquohow good a big gardenrsquo they had until coronavirus regulations made them.ldquoWersquore lucky we have so much space herersquo, he added.Table service will be the only option upon customers ing, as to not have so many people crowding a particular space wanting to order food or drink.The pub garden is being prepared for Monday ldquoTable service is ten times better than people going to the bar, and people like it, added Mr Newman.ldquoItrsquos a lot safer and lets us employ a lot more staff, as wersquove made more money from it.The club previously had one member of staff to help with the bar, now they have taken on .     Before the pandemic, Mr Newman says the clubs turnover would have been around pound,, but in the past year, from the success of their beer garden, that has turned into half a million.ldquoWe had two ways of looking at it - we could wait for things to happen, but instead we did something, he said.When asked about the Christmas lockdown on December , Ms Clare said it lsquowas neededrsquo.At the end of November last year, the seven-day coronavirus rate for Wales was  cases per , people but that then shot up to  cases per , by mid-December.The Welsh Government took unavoidable action to place Wales under Tier  restrictions and changed Christmas arrangements after receiving information about the spread of the iant in the country.ldquoYou could see it coming, addedMs Clare.ldquoYou almost donrsquot want to open when itrsquos like that anyway.Both say the Vale of Glamorgan Council have been lsquovery goodrsquo with providing grants to the club while they have been closed.ldquoWersquove had regular grants and only had to chase now and then but thatrsquos likely due to the number of businesses theyrsquore providing for, said Mr Newman.ldquoItrsquos kept us afloat.The benches were made by the rugby club members Both say they canrsquot wait for Monday but know that it is going to be a busy week due to them already being fully booked.ldquoItrsquos nice as wersquove been shut for such a long time. Itrsquos going to go from dead, to mental!The Deck at Penarth marina will also be reopening on Monday their Jetty Bar and Balcony.They have also installed a new canopy that covers the balcony area, ready for any and all-weather changes.There is limited space for bookings, so to find out more head towww.thedeckpenarth.Ben Coates, bar manager atPenarth Lawn Tennis Club, said everyone is lsquoreally excitedrsquo to be opening their club grounds to members again.Penarth Lawn Tennis Club pub garden. Picture taken before the pandemic. ldquoWe believe we have one of the best spaces in Penarth to offer members the opportunity to play and socialise, he added.ldquoWe have spent time organising the club grounds, so theyrsquore set up for maximum social distancing and have built a new outside bar to serve our members.ldquoNew members are welcome to the club and all information can be found on the clubs webpage:https:clubspark.lta.org.uk PenarthLTC.On The Rocks owner Steve,based in Sully, said: ldquoThe last fourmonths has been extremely dficult for all of us in this trade thats for sure, its long overdue that we can open all be it outside only!On The Rocks pub garden area. Picture: On The RocksldquoWe need to get back to some normality as soon as possible.ldquoOn The Rocks will be serving our great milkshakes snacks and coffee along with alcoholic drinks too until we can use inside again the food being served will be from the Seashore Grill.ldquoWe have a good outside space between the two restaurants with an amazing roof garden at the Seashore Grill also.For more information head to @ThePinkFloydBar on Facebook.Welsh Government guidance says that walk-ups should be kept to a minimum butthere is capacity and venue is allowing it, yes.Where possible pre-booking is recommended for pubs across Wales, with the details of all members of a group taken as part of the booking and checked by staff on arrival.Here are some other pub gardens that our readers recommended:The Railway, Plymouth RoadManor House, Sully RoadThe Oystercatcher, Terra Nova WayThe Captainrsquos We, Beach Road, SullyPickfords Galley  Bar with Rooms, The Esplanade article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPub-goers have waited months for this day, and now they will be allowed to have a pint outdoors as coronavirus rates drop.Hayley Clare, bar manager, and Stephen Newman, chairman, at Penarth Athletic Club said that they have been lsquobusyrsquo setting up the outdoor pub garden ready for when they can welcome back customers and members on Monday.They will also be hosting a iety of local businesses to use their kitchen to cook food for those attending, such as Crepe Escape and Onzon Thai.Speaking about the past year, Ms Clare, who started working at the club in September of last year, said that they took the lockdowns as their opportunity to look at where they were, what they were doing and make some changes as there were some issues with parts of the building and they were granted the time to upgrade.Hayley and StephenThe current Welsh Government law only allows hospitality to open outside, and the club has a big space of green land to make use of which can host around  people - but only two households per table.Marquees are also being installed to create some shelter in case the weather decides to change.Mr Newman has described the past year as lsquomadnessrsquo, and that theyrsquod never realised lsquohow good a big gardenrsquo they had until coronavirus regulations made them.ldquoWersquore lucky we have so much space herersquo, he added.Table service will be the only option upon customers ing, as to not have so many people crowding a particular space wanting to order food or drink.The pub garden is being prepared for Monday ldquoTable service is ten times better than people going to the bar, and people like it, added Mr Newman.ldquoItrsquos a lot safer and lets us employ a lot more staff, as wersquove made more money from it.The club previously had one member of staff to help with the bar, now they have taken on .     Before the pandemic, Mr Newman says the clubs turnover would have been around pound,, but in the past year, from the success of their beer garden, that has turned into half a million.ldquoWe had two ways of looking at it - we could wait for things to happen, but instead we did something, he said.When asked about the Christmas lockdown on December , Ms Clare said it lsquowas neededrsquo.At the end of November last year, the seven-day coronavirus rate for Wales was  cases per , people but that then shot up to  cases per , by mid-December.The Welsh Government took unavoidable action to place Wales under Tier  restrictions and changed Christmas arrangements after receiving information about the spread of the iant in the country.ldquoYou could see it coming, addedMs Clare.ldquoYou almost donrsquot want to open when itrsquos like that anyway.Both say the Vale of Glamorgan Council have been lsquovery goodrsquo with providing grants to the club while they have been closed.ldquoWersquove had regular grants and only had to chase now and then but thatrsquos likely due to the number of businesses theyrsquore providing for, said Mr Newman.ldquoItrsquos kept us afloat.The benches were made by the rugby club members Both say they canrsquot wait for Monday but know that it is going to be a busy week due to them already being fully booked.ldquoItrsquos nice as wersquove been shut for such a long time. Itrsquos going to go from dead, to mental!The Deck at Penarth marina will also be reopening on Monday their Jetty Bar and Balcony.They have also installed a new canopy that covers the balcony area, ready for any and all-weather changes.There is limited space for bookings, so to find out more head towww.thedeckpenarth.Ben Coates, bar manager atPenarth Lawn Tennis Club, said everyone is lsquoreally excitedrsquo to be opening their club grounds to members again.Penarth Lawn Tennis Club pub garden. Picture taken before the pandemic. ldquoWe believe we have one of the best spaces in Penarth to offer members the opportunity to play and socialise, he added.ldquoWe have spent time organising the club grounds, so theyrsquore set up for maximum social distancing and have built a new outside bar to serve our members.ldquoNew members are welcome to the club and all information can be found on the clubs webpage:https:clubspark.lta.org.uk PenarthLTC.On The Rocks owner Steve,based in Sully, said: ldquoThe last fourmonths has been extremely dficult for all of us in this trade thats for sure, its long overdue that we can open all be it outside only!On The Rocks pub garden area. Picture: On The RocksldquoWe need to get back to some normality as soon as possible.ldquoOn The Rocks will be serving our great milkshakes snacks and coffee along with alcoholic drinks too until we can use inside again the food being served will be from the Seashore Grill.ldquoWe have a good outside space between the two restaurants with an amazing roof garden at the Seashore Grill also.For more information head to @ThePinkFloydBar on Facebook.Welsh Government guidance says that walk-ups should be kept to a minimum butthere is capacity and venue is allowing it, yes.Where possible pre-booking is recommended for pubs across Wales, with the details of all members of a group taken as part of the booking and checked by staff on arrival.Here are some other pub gardens that our readers recommended:The Railway, Plymouth RoadManor House, Sully RoadThe Oystercatcher, Terra Nova WayThe Captainrsquos We, Beach Road, SullyPickfords Galley  Bar with Rooms, The Esplanade article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: trussell trust show food bank use increase wales
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThat is according to the latest Trussell Trust report, which reveals foodbanks in its network across Wales handed out , emergency food parcels to people facing crisis between April  and March .These figures mark an eight per cent increase on the the previous year, when , parcels were handed out.It is also a  per cent increase since  .The Trust say these figures are just the tip of the iceberg, with a number of people being helped by other food aid providers and community groups that sprang up during the pandemic.Susan Lloyd-Selby, the Trussell Trustrsquos operations manager for Wales, said: ldquoNo one should#face the#indignity of#needing#emergency food."Yet our network of food banks across Wales continue to provide huge numbers of food parcels as more and more people struggle without enough money for the essentials."This#is not right#but#we know we can build a better future.#This pandemic has shown the unexpected can hit suddenly, but we know when we push for change, united by our desire for justice and compassion, the government#has to#listen and act.#ldquoWersquove welcomed an increased take up of the Discretionary Assistance Fund along with extended free school meal provision, but we must go further to ensure we all have enough money for essentials.ldquoWe are asking you, the public, to write to your Senedd election candidates for a commitment to working to end the need for food banks. Together we can take action now to build#a#hunger#free future for Wales.:Hunger in the Wales isnrsquot about food, the charity says, itrsquos about people not having enough money#for the basics and with#high rates of#unemployment#and#record#redundancies, more people than ever need the#social security#system to#provide a strong#enough#leline#to#stay afloat.##     Sabine Goodwin, coordinator of the Independent Food Aid Network added: "Independent food banks in Wales are also continuing to see relentless need for their help although combined Trussell Trust and independent food bank figures represent a fraction of the food insecurity picture."Now more than ever, our UK social security system needs to be reset, the Discretionary Assistance Fund promoted and prioritised and adequate wages and secure work ensured."Its the responsibility of governments to stop hunger from happening in the first place so that everyone is able to afford to buy food and other essentials." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: driving tests allowed wales today   need know
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityHowever, there are reports that, due to a signicant backlog, there could be a wait of up to seven months to rebookthe test is failed.This could add extra pressure to an already nervous situation.We have compiled a list of all you need to know should you be thinking of booking your test asap.What will happenmy driving test is affected The Driver and Vehicle Standards Agencywill contact youyour test is affected and tell you what you need to do.How can I book my test You can still book your driving test online hereDo I have to wear a mask Yes, unless you have a good reason not to.When you arrange your test, yoursquoll need to saytherersquos a good reason you cannot wear a face covering when you take your test.This includes :- you have a physical or mental illness or impairment, or a disability that means you cannot put on, wear or remove a face covering- putting on, wearing or removing a face covering would cause you severe distress- you need to remove it during your test to avoid harm or injury or the risk of harm or injury to yourself or othersWearing glasses does not count as a good reason not to wear a face covering. You should practise driving wearing a face covering before your test to help you prepare.You might not be able to take a test at your preferred test centreyou cannot wear a face covering.IMPORTANT - Your test will be cancelledyou come for your test without a face covering and you did not declare you could not wear one when you arranged your test.Driving examiners will be wearing face coverings - they might also choose to wear gloves and use disposable seat covers.Driving instructors will not be permitted to sit in the back during your test.If you have a problem with your face covering during the test, your driving examiner will ask you to stop so you can adjust it. Your driving examiner will end the test earlyit becomes a safety issue.     Do I have to take a coronavirus test first The government have said that itrsquos best to take a rapid lateral flow test before your driving testyou do not have COVID- symptoms and yoursquore in:- England- Wales, and you cannot work from homeFor more information on the lateral flow test, click hereWhat should I do on the day Do not arrive for your driving test more than five minutes before your appointment time.Some driving test centre waiting rooms are closed to help prevent the spread of COVID-. Your driving instructor or accompanying driver can checkthe waiting room will be open before your test.Toilets are available on request, eventhe waiting room is closed.Will my car be cleaned before I use it You must clean the inside of your car before your test.This means:- tidying any unnecessary items away from the dashboard, footwells, door pockets, cup holders and seats- wiping down the dashboard and car controlsThe examiner will do an additional clean of some surfaces.The car you use for your test must have at least one window open on each side throughout the test.WhatI have coronavirus symptoms Do not go to your driving test :- you or someone you live with has COVID- symptoms- yoursquove been told to self-isolate by NHS Test and Trace or the NHS COVID- app- yoursquore quarantining because you recently entered the UKChange your test appointment or cancel your testyoursquore not able to go. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: grandmother  pfizer jab first urges people get second covid dose
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe face of Margaret Keenan ndash known as Maggie ndash made news around the world in December last year after she was given the coronavirus jab at University Hospital Coventry.In a Zoom call with NHS chief executive Sir Simon Stevens, the grandmother of four was asked what she would say to anyone feeling hesitant about getting a second jab.Mrs Keenan replied: ldquoI would be saying lsquogo and get it, and get it nowrsquo.ldquoBecause itthe best thing theyrsquove ever done, really.the best thing I ever did.ldquoI hope everybody comes forward.ldquoSome people are just afraid of injections but therersquos nothing to it.ldquoYou donrsquot feel anything. vw,vw,px, px"Margaret Keenan, with matron May Parsons Asked about how she felt being the first to have the jab, she added: ldquoI feel really honoured to have it done and to be the first and set the ball rolling.Mrs Keenan said that, having since had her second dose, she was now most looking forward to ldquoa little holiday, adding with a laugh ldquoIrsquom not greedy!The nonagenarian, who only retired from her job working in a jewellerrsquos four years ago, also praised NHS doctors and nurses for their work during the rollout.She said: ldquoTheyrsquore incredible, I cannot find words to say hellip they are really incredible for what theyrsquove done.ldquoI think the NHS has achieved an enormous lot by doing the work they do.ldquoIt is such a wonderful institution. vw,vw,px, px"Sir Simon Stevens praised Margaret Keenan Mrs Keenan, who has lived in Coventry for more than  years but is originally from Enniskillen, Northern Ireland, received the Zoom earlier this week, where she was reunited with matron May Parsons.     It was Ms Parsons, matron for respiratory medicine at University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust, who administered Mrs Keenanrsquoshistoric first jab on December  .Ms Parsons, who has worked for the NHS for almost  years since moving from the Philippines, said: ldquoThe dawn is coming, wersquore going to be coming out of this.ldquoI cannot be more excited and I canrsquot be more positive about.ldquoWersquore coming out of this pandemic, stronger.She added a ldquomassive thank you to her NHS colleagues, for their ldquocompassion, ldquobravery and courage throughout the last year. vw,vw,px, px"Mrs Keenan was the first person in the world to have the Pfizer vaccine as part of the mass vaccination rollout Thanking the pair on the call, Sir Simon said: ldquoMaggie, yoursquove been an inspiration.ldquoMay, yoursquove set the whole of the health service on the path towards this hugely successful vaccine rollout.Separately, the NHS boss said: ldquoWersquore seeing patients coming forward in record numbers for their Oxford AstraZeneca second doses.ldquoPeople are voting with their feet, showing continuing strong public support for the NHS Covid vaccination campaign which has already saved over , lives.The NHS vaccine programme, the biggest in health service history and the most rapid rollout in Europe, is continuing to ramp up second doses for the most vulnerable.The programme has now protected about  million people in England with at least one jab, also delivering more than nine million second doses." data-title"HEALTH Coronavirus" data--holder"PA Graphics" data--notice"PA Graphics Press Association Images" data-credit"PA Graphics" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eaebbaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjEMTcMzU ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eaebbaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjEMTcMzU ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eaebbaYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjEMTcMzU ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Although the NHS focus is on second doses, appointments are still available for those in the initial priority groups who have not yet been protected.People who had their first jab at a vaccination centre or pharmacy-led service should already have a date for their second while those jabbed by a GP will be called back.Anyone aged  and over can still arrange their jab, as well as people who are clinically vulnerable or a health and care worker, who should contact their GP for an appointment.The NHS is also inviting those eligible for a jab by letter and text, with some GPs also calling unvaccinated patients personally to encourage uptake.Doctors, nurses and other health care workers are administering injections at more than , sites, from cathedrals, mosques and temples to racecourses, stadiums, cinemas and museums.More than  of those sites have begun offering the Moderna jab over the title: us pledge halve emissions  moves world closer climate target
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe US presidentrsquos new target aims to achieve a -% reduction in emissions from  levels by , a move which the White House said would create millions of jobs, cut energy costs and boost nature.Analysts said the move is ldquomajor progress on previous US commitments, and helps reduce the gap between the action needed to curb dangerous global warming and what countries have pledged to do ndash although it is not quite enough to bring America in line with achieving international climate goals.The move comes at the start of a virtual climate summit convened by Mr Biden, where Boris Johnson will tell fellow world leaders that  must be the year countries ldquoget serious about stopping climate change.The Prime Minister this week announced a ldquoworld-leading target for the UK to cut emissions by % on  levels by , which builds on plans to cut pollution by % by , the most ambitious among leading economies.But campaigners in the UK have warned that policies and action are urgently needed to deliver on the pledges and cut pollution from homes, transport, industry and power supplies.Mr Johnson is expected to tell the meeting: ldquoThe UK has shown that itrsquos possible to slash emissions while growing the economy, which makes the question of reaching net zero not so much technical as political.ldquoIf we actually want to stop climate change, then this must be the year in which we get serious about doing so.ldquoBecause the s will be remembered either as the decade in which world leaders united to turn the tide, or as a failure.The summit comes after the International Energy Agency warned that global carbon emissions were set for their second biggest increase on record after a sharp drop in  due to the pandemic, with demand for fossil fuels, including coal, pushing climate pollution up to close to  levels.     The two-day US-led summit will also hear from leaders of major economies including China, Japan, Russia, Canada, India and Australia, who will be watched closely to see what ambition they will bring to the table.#PresidentBidens new #ParisAgreement target is the biggest US step forward on #climate in history would close the  global #emissions gap by -%. Not yet .#C compatible, but well on the way. Our analysis #NDC https:t.co XEcgGWkXf #LeadersSummitonClimate pic QruamIMYmdash ClimateActionTrackerApril , Japan and Canada are among the countries expected to unveil new climate targets at the meeting, while the European Union has agreed a new climate law which includes a goal to cut its emissions by % by  on  levels.As part of diplomatic efforts in the lead-up to the summit, the US and China issued a statement pledging to work together and with other countries on the issue.The US reduction ndash estimated to be around a -% cut on  levels ndash is part of the USrsquos national climate plan, which it is submitting as part of itsto the Paris climate accord, the worldrsquos first comprehensive climate treaty which Donald Trump quit when he was president.Countries have been expected to come forward with more ambitious plans up to , known as nationally determined contributionsin the Paris deal, ahead of Cop in November.That is because existing plans are not enough to meet countriesrsquo commitments under the Paris deal to curb global temperature rises to ldquowell below C above pre-industrial levels ndash or .Cpossible ndash and avoid the most dangerous impacts of climate change.Analysts at Climate Action Tracker said the new US target was a signicant step forward and would reduce the global emissions gap between action pledged and the cuts needed to meet the Paris goals by around -% in .But bigger cuts of -% by  would be needed for the US to play its part in meeting the .C target and put the country on a better track to achieving its pledge to cut emissions to net zero by .The summit, which will have sessions on increasing climate action, finance for developing countries, the role of natural solutions such as restoring forests and peatlands, and security impacts of climate change, will also hear from United Nations secretary general Antonio Guterres and Pope Francis..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: US pledge to halve emissions by  moves world closer to climate target article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: new research reveals british parents need education childrens nutrition
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMost are confident their children already get a good diet but  per cent reported their kids donrsquot get enough iety in their diet,  per cent admitted their children are not active enough and more than one in tenbelieve their kids donrsquot get enough dairy.Parentsrsquo gaps in understanding have been revealed by new insights from dairy cooperative, Arla.More than eight in ten surveyed admitted they donrsquot know how much calcium their children need, with the research revealing a lack of understanding about nutrition.Just  per cent admitted their kids regularly achieved their recommended dietary allowances while  per cent ten in four admit their kids donrsquot hit their five-a-day target.ldquoTherersquos a lot of information out there and it can be hard for parents to know what they can trust, but I share the beliefwe start to educate kids while theyrsquore young, wersquore helping to set them up to make the best possible choices as they grow up, said nutritionist Rhiannon Lambert.To help tackle the issues around nutrition education, one Arla farmer, Jonny Burridge and his cow Jelly, are on a mission to help parents and children understand more, alongside registered nutritionist, Rhiannon Lambert.Launching their first book last year to share sustainable farm experiences with families, their second book - Jonny and Jelly Go from Strength to Strength - focuses on nutrition and educating the whole family on a well-balanced diet.## Jonny and Jelly are back! ##Arla farmer, Jonny, and his cow, Jelly, are on a mission to help childrenunderstand where food comes from and what we need for a balanced diet. https:t.co BGFjIkwfM #FuelForLearningmdash Arla Dairy UKApril , ldquoWhat an honour for Jelly and me to be involved in a second book, this time to help children and their families understand nutrition," said Burridge.     "Jelly is of course the star of the show and has helped to immerse kids in farming and the wonderful outdoors throughout her le."Shersquos actually met over , children in her letime, and made numerous visits to local schools, shows and events. I personally think of milk as one of naturersquos nectars but, of course, I am biased.Research from dairy cooperative Arla revealed the startling findings"But I do know that dairy can play a really important role in a healthy and balanced diet and I really hope this book helps more children to learn about it.Arlas Danny Micklethwaite added: " Of the parents we surveyed, one in tensaid they didnrsquot know where to find information about childrenrsquos optimum nutrition, and they donrsquot trust any particular sources to educate them. This is something we feel we have a responsibility to help change. We are owned by over , farmers - all as passionate as Jonny about helping kids gain a good understanding of how their food gets in front of them and what it contains to help them fuel their bodies.To find out more, or download the book, visit www.arlafoods forward-thinking-dairy jonny-and-jelly-go-from-strength-to-strength . title: call for new strategy to restore our woodlands
story: Dozens of pupils sent home after positive COVID test at NI college   Semi-permanent speed devices to be erected across Armagh Banbridge and Craigavon Council areaNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsCall for new strategy to restore our woodlandsCalls have been made for a new strategy to restore our local woodlands.By Carmel RobinsonWednesday, st April , : pm  "       "  It follows ‘ground-breaking’ research on NI forests by the Woodland Trust.SDLP MLA Dolores Kelly, sponsor of draft Environment and Nature Restoration legislation at Stormont, said that the scarcity of local woodlands is contributing to a bioersity crisis.Party colleague Patsy McGlone MLA, a member of the Stormont Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs Committee, called for a new strategy to incentivise greater numbers of land managers to invest in ecosystem services.Dolores Kelly .Mrs Kelly said: “Woodland coverage in Northern Ireland is among the worst across these islands.“Our forests and wooded areas provide a much needed break from our increasingly urbanised lives and there’s no doubt that, over the last  months, people have started to reconnect with our natural environment.“But woodlands are primarily an important habitat for plant and animal species that are being squeezed by human encroachment. “It is a shocking assessment that just % of land here is forest. “The stripping back of what was once a temperate rainforest in this part of the world is creating a severe bioersity crisis that needs to be addressed immediately,” said Mrs Kelly.“That is why I am seeking to give statutory underpinning to bioersity targets that will include the restoration of our rich woodlands.”Mr McGlone said: “Woodlands are incredibly important as a habitat and source of bioersity, particularly in rural communities. “But they also provide an important way to absorb excess carbon in our atmosphere, helping to address the climate crisis.“The Executive should urgently consider a robust new strategy to incentivise land managers to invest in ecosystem services, like managing woodlands to increase our carbon sequestration capacity. “As the future of land management remains in flux as a result of Brexit, we have an opportunity to invest in ecologically positive practice that restores nature and secures the future of rural businesses,” said the Mid Ulster SDLP MLA.‘Shock’ as leline for troubled Co Armagh medical practice is withdrawn Read full story here--Editor’s Message:Thank you for reading this article. title: dozens of pupils sent home after positive covid test at ni college
story: Horror as bags of dead lambs found during evening stroll   Semi-permanent speed devices to be erected across Armagh Banbridge and Craigavon Council areaNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleDozens of pupils sent home after positive COVID test at NI collegeDozens of pupils have been sent home from an NI college after a positive COVID- test.By Carmel RobinsonThursday, th April , : pmUpdated Thursday, th April , : pm  "       "  It is understood around  pupils were sent home from Lurgan College on Wednesday - just days after ing back to school this week.Some pupils and parents voiced disappointment that they had to go home so soon after getting back to school on Monday.Principal Trevor Robinson said: “I can confirm that a member of our school community tested positive for Covid-. Lurgan College. Photo courtesy of Google.“I have assured parents that I have sought and followed the most up-to-date advice from the Public Health Agency .“I appreciate the concerns of parents, pupils and the wider school community and I have reassured them that every precaution has been taken in line with advice from PHA.“Ensuring the safety of pupils and staff remains the school’s absolute priority.”Horror as bags of dead lambs found during evening stroll Read full story here--Editor’s Message:Thank you for reading this article. title: phone first before going to emergency department
story: Call for new strategy to restore our woodlands   Man arrested after reports of car driving erratically near M junctionNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeople‘Phone first’ before going to Emergency DepartmentWith lockdown restrictions lting and more leisure activities resuming, the Southern Trust is reminding people with urgent but not critical symptoms to ‘Phone first’ before attending Emergency Departments or Minor Injuries services.By The NewsroomWednesday, st April , : pm  "       "  Patients, including children, considering attending Emergency Departments or the Minor Injuries Services at Craigavon, Daisy Hill or South Tyrone Hospital with an urgent but not le threatening injury or illness should Phone     Monday to Friday am to pm.The ‘Phone first’ approach aims to help those patients fit to ‘walk in’ to the Emergency Department , get the most appropriate care as quickly as possible and avoid busy waiting rooms. When you ring the number, a call handler takes your details. A Senior Nurse, Physiotherapist or GP will then call you back and advise on the most suitable care. For some patients, they will advise how to self-manage their condition or direct them to their community pharmacist. Those who need urgent assessment or treatment may receive an appointment with a Physiotherapist, an urgent care GP, or could be referred to another service like Minor Injuries or their own GP.Craigavon Area Hospital. Pic by PACEMAKER PRESSDr Rosemary Sloan, Clinical Lead for Urgent Care in the Southern Health and Social Care Trust explains: “The COVID- pandemic has created unprecedented challenges across health and social care, highlighting the importance of working together to improve access to our services and prioritise those who need them most. “With increasing numbers of patients attending unscheduled care services in recent weeks, for everyone’s safety and to reduce the potential spread of infection amongst both patients and staff, we must do our very best to minimise footfall and promote social distancing in all health care facilities.“Since we opened the ‘Phone First’ telephone line, only about one third of patients who call the number need to attend the Emergency Department whilst we have been able redirect others to a more suitable service, avoiding a potential y wait in a busy waiting room.“As alwaysyou think the symptoms are potentially critical, like a heart attack, stroke, or major trauma, please do not delay in phoning an ambulance or getting the patient to the Emergency Departmentyou can.“For everyone , please phone first for advice and support to find the best place to treat your condition.”Editor’s message:Thank you for reading this article.
